source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

This means 17,000 are still missing. In 2013, a 19-metre asteroid exploded over Chelyabinsk, Russia. It hurt 1,200 people. So, these medium-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they come near Earth.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.

Everyone has to watch the event on TV.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. But in recent years, the world's press has been full of reports of wild animals coming into cities in bigger and bigger numbers. There have been bears in Vancouver parks, leopards on the streets of Mumbai and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when bigger animals come into our cities? Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

In Vancouver, there are bears in the parks. In Mumbai, leopards are on the streets. In Berlin, wild pigs are in the gardens. What happens when big animals come into our cities? Are people happy to see them, or do they think these animals are dangerous or a problem?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PHAs, none of which are expected to be a threat in the next one hundred years. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

Martel's father was a diplomat, so he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico as a child.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After my parental leave, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I talked to my boss, and we decided I would work only three days a week. This means I now earn less money because I work fewer days. But I have noticed that I still have the same amount of work as before. So, I am doing five days of work in just three days, but I earn less money for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with other countries. Most business people use English to talk, but they have different ways of talking and doing things in business. If we do not know these differences, we might judge people unfairly or not understand them well. This can cause problems. There are three main differences in how people do business in different cultures. Knowing these can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

Human brains did not suddenly become bigger. But humans did become smarter and more complex. Did using language make their brains grow? Or did their smarter brains begin creating language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Over the last ten years, big supermarkets have been in trouble for doing bad things. They have thrown away a lot of food, paid too little to their suppliers, and used too much plastic, which is bad for the environment. But now, supermarkets are paying attention. People are unhappy about the plastic waste from packaging. So, some big UK supermarkets have agreed to use better packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

Wasfia only watched because, in her country, people thought girls should not use hula hoops or ride bikes. Now, Wasfia has climbed the Seven Summits, which include Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is the first person to hula-hoop on each of these mountains. She does this to show support for women and girls in her country, where people often say they should not play sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: We think Girox Foods should focus more on its people. We suggest offering flexible working hours. Employees could also work from places they choose. Managers should find ways to challenge staff and praise their good work. Spending more on training, especially in talking with others and understanding different cultures, can help make a good place to work. This will help employees do their best.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, better technology and health helped more children live. This caused the population to grow quickly. Big families had more children who grew up and had their own kids. But in the 1960s, more people used birth control. The average number of babies per woman went down from six to two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Understanding that people from different cultures may think and act differently helps us talk better with them. But, we should not use stereotypes, which are ideas about how all people from one place are the same. Stereotypes can make business relationships bad. Our culture can affect us, but so can where we live, who we know, how old we are, if we are male or female, our work culture, and our own life experiences. We should remember that people may be different, but we shouldn't judge everyone from one country the same way.

We should keep these possible differences in mind but not use them to label people from a whole country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

This change is linked to speaking and how our brains move our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not change. We do not know exactly how much genes affect language yet, but answers might be in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. If these medium-sized asteroids come near Earth, they can be very dangerous.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work for five days a week. After my parental leave, I wanted to be with my children more before they go to school. I talked to my boss, and we agreed that I would work only three days a week. This means I now earn less money because I work fewer days. But I still have the same amount of work as before. Now, I do the work of five days in just three days, but I get paid less for it.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate:
Today, many businesses work with people from other countries. Most people in business use English, but the way they talk and act can be very different in each culture. If we don't understand the way people from other cultures do things, it can lead to wrong ideas, mistakes, and problems in talking to each other.

Here are three simple things to remember about how business manners can be different around the world. These tips can help you when you work with someone from another culture:

1. Pay attention to how people from other cultures speak and behave.
2. Learn about their customs and what is important to them.
3. Be open and ready to learn from others to avoid misunderstandings.

Knowing these differences can help you work better with people from different cultures.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

They have wasted a lot of food, paid their suppliers too little, and used too much plastic in packaging, which is bad for the environment. But now, supermarkets are starting to pay attention and make changes. Because many customers are unhappy about the large amounts of plastic waste, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK have agreed to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate: When Wasfia Nazreen was a young girl, she saw a child from another country playing with a hula hoop in Bangladesh. Wasfia watched but did not play because people in her country thought girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now, Wasfia has climbed the Seven Summits, like Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is the first person to use a hula hoop on each peak. She wants to help girls and women in her country feel strong and free to do sports.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology and health got better. This meant fewer children died young, so the population grew quickly. Big families had more children, and those children grew up. They then had their own families. But in the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. Because of this, women now have fewer babies. The average number of babies per woman went from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
Understanding that people might expect or act differently can help us avoid misunderstandings. But we must remember that thinking all people from one culture are the same can harm good business relationships.

Our behavior and thoughts might be shaped by our national culture. But many other things influence us too. These are where we live, the groups we join, our age and gender, the culture at our workplace, and our personal experiences.

It is important to know that differences exist. But we should not use this knowledge to judge everyone in a nation as the same.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

This shows that these medium-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they come close to Earth.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

I now do five days' work in three days but earn less money.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

Here are three simple areas where business manners are different around the world. Knowing these can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They will change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.

So, we should keep these possible differences in mind. However, we should not use them to judge everyone from a whole country the same way.

There are bears in Vancouver’s parks, leopards on Mumbai’s streets, and wild pigs in Berlin’s gardens. What happens when these bigger animals come into our cities? Do people welcome them, or do they see them as dangerous or a problem?

source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. The only programmes she could find on TV were 'reality' programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars and news programmes about the war. Suzanne says that the two things start to merge together in a disturbing way and the idea for The Hunger Games came to her.

This gave her the idea for The Hunger Games.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After I returned from my parental leave, I decided I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I spoke with my boss, and we agreed that I would only work three days a week. Because of this change, I now earn less money. However, my workload did not get any smaller. I am doing five days of work in only three days, but I am paid much less.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate:
Today, many businesses work with people from other countries. Many people use English to communicate. However, business communication can still differ from one culture to another.

If we do not understand other people’s cultures, we may judge them unfairly. This can lead to misunderstandings and communication problems.

Below are three basic differences in business customs around the world. Learning about these differences can help you when you work with someone from a different culture.

Knowing these differences can be very helpful when you work with someone from another culture.

Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

They have thrown away a lot of food, paid some of their suppliers very little, and used too much plastic in their packages. This plastic waste has harmed our environment. However, these supermarkets and grocers are now paying attention. Many people are angry about the huge amount of plastic waste. In response, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed a promise. They will change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
Wasfia Nazreen saw a hula hoop for the first time when she was a young girl. She watched a visiting child from another country play with it in Bangladesh. People in her country believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bicycles, so she only watched.

Today, Wasfia is one of the few people in the world who have climbed the Seven Summits, including Mount Everest and Mount Kilimanjaro. She is also the first to use a hula hoop on each mountain. She does this to give strength and hope to women and girls in a country that does not encourage them to play sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. These steps can help create a positive work environment where everyone can do their best.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: Over the past 200 years, better technology and healthcare helped more children survive. As a result, the population grew very quickly. Families had many children who lived to become adults and start their own families. Then, in the 1960s, contraception became easier to get. Because of this, the average number of babies per woman went down from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
Being aware that people have different expectations and ways of behaving can help us avoid misunderstandings. However, it is also important to remember that using cultural stereotypes can harm good business relationships. 

Our national culture may influence how we think and act. But we are also shaped by where we live, the groups of people around us, our age and gender, our work culture, and the experiences we have in life. 

We should keep these possible differences in mind, but we should not assume that everyone from the same country acts in the same way.

The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.

These include our home region, the groups we belong to, our age and gender, our company culture, and our individual life experiences. We should keep in mind that these differences exist, but we should not use them to label everyone from an entire country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate: Scientists study how our genes affect our brain and language. They ask if some genes changed (mutated) long ago and helped people develop language. Researchers found one gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This gene seems to help us speak and move our mouths and faces. Monkeys have a similar gene, but theirs did not change. We still do not know exactly how much genes affect language. One day, the answers might be in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

I still do the same amount of work as before, but in only three days, and for less pay.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Below are three main differences in business manners that may help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

They promise to change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
When Wasfia Nazreen was a young girl, she saw a foreign child playing with a hula hoop in Bangladesh. She wanted to play too, but she did not because many people believed girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes.

Later, Wasfia climbed the Seven Summits, including Mount Everest and Mount Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula hoop on each of these high mountains. She does this to support women and girls in her country, where many people still discourage them from playing sports.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

Large families had many children who grew up and had their own children. In the 1960s, birth control (contraception) became easier to get. Because of this, the average number of babies each woman had went down from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
When we understand that people can have different expectations and ways of behaving, we can avoid misunderstandings. But we should also remember that stereotypes about cultures can harm good business relationships.

National culture can shape how we act and think. However, we are also influenced by where we live, the people around us, our age, our gender, our workplace culture, and our personal experiences.

We should keep these possible differences in mind, but we should not use them to judge everyone from one country in exactly the same way.

NASA has made a map showing about 1,400 of these asteroids. None of them should hit Earth in the next 100 years. Today’s technology lets NASA watch these rocks and predict if one might crash into Earth. If a real danger appears, NASA already has two possible ways to protect the planet.

If any asteroid does become dangerous, NASA has two possible ways to defend our planet and change the asteroid’s path.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

He is alone in a small lifeboat on the Pacific Ocean.  
A big, dangerous tiger is in the boat with him.  

The writer of the book is Yann Martel.  
He is Canadian.  
Life of Pi is his third book.  
It was published in 2001.  

The book is very popular.  
More than seven million copies have been sold around the world.  
It has won many prizes.  
It has been translated into 41 languages.  

Yann Martel’s father was a diplomat.  
When Yann was a child, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico.

candidate:
“Life of Pi” is a novel about Pi, a teenage boy from India. After his ship sinks, Pi is alone in a small lifeboat on the Pacific Ocean with a fierce tiger.  
The book was written by Canadian author Yann Martel. It is his third novel and was first published in 2001.  
Since then, more than seven million copies have been sold around the world. The book has won many prizes and has been translated into 41 languages.  
Martel’s father was a diplomat, so when Martel was a child he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico.

source: Dreams of a phone call from an old friend or the death of someone close, for example, are more likely to be the result of coincidence than prophecy. And, of course, we probably choose to forget all the times we dream about such events but they don't happen.
candidate: If you dream that an old friend calls you, or that someone close to you dies, it is probably just chance. It is not telling the future. We also often forget the many dreams like this that never come true.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In some cases, this could happen because inferior-quality material was used in the construction, or because of a defect in a key piece of the bridge. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.
candidate: Sometimes a bridge falls down and no one knows why. Engineers must study the broken bridge to find out the cause. One reason can be that the builders used weak or poor materials. Another reason can be a problem in an important part of the bridge. A bridge can also fall if it was built to carry only a small weight, but later had to carry more.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate:
I used to work five days each week.  
After my parental leave ended, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school.  
I spoke with my boss. We agreed that I will now work only three days each week.  
Because I work fewer days, I earn less money (my pay is pro-rata).  

But my amount of work did not get smaller. I still must finish five days of work in only three days, and I receive less pay for it.

I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

However, my amount of work has not become smaller. I still do five days of work in only three days, but I earn less money.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many companies work with people from other countries. Most business people use English, but each culture still has its own way of speaking and behaving. These differences can be big. If we do not know the customs of our business partners, we can judge them unfairly. We may also misunderstand them, and communication can fail. Below are three simple areas of business manners that often change from country to country. Learning about them can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

If we do not understand these cultural rules, we may judge others unfairly, misunderstand them, or even stop the conversation by mistake.

Below are three main areas where business etiquette differs around the world. Knowing these areas will help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate:
In the last ten years, many big supermarkets have been criticised. People say they throw away a lot of food, pay suppliers too little, and use too much plastic packaging. This plastic harms the environment.

Now, supermarkets are starting to listen. Many customers are unhappy about the plastic waste. Because of this, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have made a promise. They will change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
Wasfia Nazreen is from Bangladesh.

When she was a little girl, she saw a visitor from another country playing with a hula hoop.  
Wasfia only watched.  
Many people in Bangladesh said girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes.

Now Wasfia is grown up and very strong.  
She has climbed the Seven Summits—the highest mountains on every continent, such as Everest and Kilimanjaro.  
She is the first person to hula-hoop on the top of each mountain.

Wasfia does this to give hope and strength to women and girls in Bangladesh.  
She wants to show that girls can do sports too.

Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:

Today, Wasfia is one of the few people in the world who have climbed the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent, including Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on every one of these peaks.

She does this to give strength and confidence to women and girls in Bangladesh, where they are often told not to do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate:
Simplified Document:

Our study shows that Girox Foods should care more about its people.  
First, give workers flexible hours.  
Second, let them choose where to work, for example at home or in the office.  

Managers should:  
• give workers new and interesting tasks, and  
• say “well done” when workers do good work.  

The company should also spend more money on training, especially training in how to talk with people from different cultures.  

These steps will make a happier workplace and help everyone do their best work.

We advise Girox Foods to use a management style that cares more about people. First, give employees more flexible working hours. Let them choose where they work, for example, from home or another place.

Managers should also give staff different tasks that make them think and learn. They should praise and thank employees when they do good work.

Finally, the company should spend more money on training. This training should include how to communicate well with people from other cultures. All these steps will help create a positive workplace where employees can do their best.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate:
In the last 200 years, technology and health care became better. Because of this, fewer children died. So the world population grew very fast.

Many families were big. Their children lived to become adults and then had their own children.

In the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. After that, women began to have fewer babies. On average, the number went down from about six babies per woman to about two.

candidate:

In the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. After that, women started to have fewer children. The average number went down from about six children per woman to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
If we understand that people can have different ideas and ways of acting, we can stop many mix-ups when we talk to them. But we must also remember not to use fixed ideas about a culture, because this can hurt our business relationships.

Our country does influence how we think and behave. However, many other things influence us too: 
• the area where we live  
• the groups we belong to  
• our age and gender  
• the company culture at our workplace  
• our own life experiences  

So, keep these possible differences in mind, but do not put all people from one country into the same box.

The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
If we understand that people may have different expectations and ways of acting, we can avoid misunderstandings. At the same time, we must remember that using cultural stereotypes can damage good business relationships.  

Yes, our national culture can influence how we think and behave. However, many other factors also shape us. These include the region where we live, the groups we belong to, our age, our gender, the culture of our workplace, and our own life experiences.  

So, keep these possible differences in mind, but do not place everyone from one country into the same category.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate:
Simplified Document:

We still have many questions about how genes shape our brain and our language.  

Did some genes change and give us the ability to speak?  

Scientists found one gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This change seems to help us talk and to move our mouth and face.  

Monkeys have almost the same gene, but their gene did not change in this way.  

We do not yet know how much genes affect language. Maybe one day we will find the answer in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate: Scientists want to understand how our genes affect the brain and language. They ask: Did some genes change and give humans the power to speak? Monkeys have almost the same gene, but their gene did not change in this way. We still do not know exactly how much genes shape language. Maybe one day we will find a clear answer in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.
candidate:
NASA is now making a list of smaller asteroids.  
These asteroids are 140 meters wide or bigger.  

Scientists think there are about 25,000 asteroids of this size.  
NASA has already written down about 8,000 of them.  
This means about 17,000 are still not on the list.  

In 2013, a 19-meter asteroid exploded over the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia.  
It hurt 1,200 people.  

This shows that medium-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they come close to Earth.

Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In some cases, this could happen because inferior-quality material was used in the construction, or because of a defect in a key piece of the bridge. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.
candidate:
Sometimes a bridge falls down and people do not know why. Engineers must study the bridge carefully to find the reason. 

One reason could be that the builders used weak or poor-quality materials. Another reason could be that an important part of the bridge had a fault. 

Also, some bridges are made to carry only a certain amount of weight. If the weight is heavier than this limit, the bridge can collapse.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After my parental leave, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I talked with my boss and we agreed that I would work only three days a week. Because I work fewer days, I now earn less money. However, my amount of work did not change. I still have to finish five days of work in just three days, but I am paid less for it.

I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate:
I used to work five days each week. After my parental leave, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I talked with my boss, and we agreed that I would work only three days a week. Because I now work fewer days, I also earn less money, as my pay is reduced to match my hours.

However, I have noticed a problem. My amount of work has not gone down. I still need to do the same tasks that fill five days, but I must finish them in only three days. So I am doing the work of five days while receiving the pay of three days.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with people in other countries. Most people use English, but each culture communicates in its own way. If we do not know these cultural rules, we can judge others wrongly, misunderstand them, and stop good communication. Below are three simple differences in business manners around the world. Learning them can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

We do not know how these pictures are linked to language. Human brains did not suddenly get bigger, but people did become smarter. Did speaking help their brains grow? Or did smarter brains help people start speaking?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

Simplified Document:

Many big supermarket companies have been blamed for bad actions in the last ten years. They throw away a lot of food. They pay the people who sell them goods too little money. They also use too much plastic in their packages, and this harms the environment.

Now these supermarkets are starting to listen. Shoppers are angry about all the plastic. Because of this, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK have made a promise. They will change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
Wasfia Nazreen first saw a hula hoop when she was a little girl in Bangladesh. A child from another country was visiting and playing with it. Wasfia watched but did not play, because many people in her country thought girls should not use hula hoops or ride bikes.

Today, Wasfia is a very strong climber. She has climbed the highest mountain on every continent, like Everest and Kilimanjaro. Very few people have done this. She is also the first person to spin a hula hoop on the top of each mountain.

Wasfia does this to give hope and power to women and girls in Bangladesh, where many still say girls should not do sports.

Today, Wasfia’s life has changed. She has climbed the Seven Summits—the highest mountains on each continent, such as Everest and Kilimanjaro. Only a few people have done this. On every peak, she also used a hula hoop. She did this to show women and girls in Bangladesh that they can do sports and be strong.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.

We advise Girox Foods to care more about its workers.  
The company should let employees choose flexible work hours and work from places they like.  

Managers need to:  
• Give staff new and interesting tasks.  
• Praise and thank them for their good work.  

The company should also spend more money on training.  
Training in social and intercultural communication is very important.  
This will help create a happy workplace where everyone can do their best work.

Spending more money on training, especially in social skills and intercultural communication, can help create a positive workplace where employees do their best.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate:
Simplified Document:  

In the last 200 years, new machines and better medicine helped more children stay alive. Because of this, families became big and the world population grew fast. These children grew up and had their own children. In the 1960s, birth control became easy to get. After this, women had fewer babies. The world average fell from about six babies per woman to about two.

On average, the number of babies per woman fell from about six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
Simplified Document:

If we know that people can have different hopes and ways of acting, we can avoid misunderstandings. But we must also remember that cultural stereotypes can harm good business relationships. 

Our country’s culture can affect how we act and think. However, many other things shape us too. These include where we live, the groups we belong to, our age and gender, the culture at our workplace, and our own life experiences. 

So, we should keep these possible differences in mind, but we should not put all people from one country into the same box.

So, keep these possible differences in mind, but do not use them to label or judge everyone from one country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate:
We still have many questions about how our genes affect the brain and language.

Did some genes change and give people the ability to speak?

Scientists found one gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago.  
This change may help us speak and control how our mouth and face move.

Monkeys have almost the same gene, but theirs did not change in this way.

We do not yet know exactly how much genes shape language.  
Maybe one day we will discover the answer by studying our DNA.

We still do not know exactly how much genes shape language. In the future, our DNA may give us the full answer.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

Because of this, these medium-sized asteroids could be very dangerous if they come near Earth.

source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After my parental leave, I wanted more time with my children before they start school. I asked my boss, and we agreed that I would work three days a week. This means I earn less money. But my work did not change at all. Now I do five days of work in three days, and I am paid less for it.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many people do business with others in different countries. Most use English to talk, but customs and expectations can change a lot from one culture to another. They might help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

Humans’ brains did not suddenly grow bigger, but people did become more developed and smarter. Maybe using language helped their brains grow. Or maybe their brains grew first and then created language.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big supermarkets have been accused of unfair actions over the last ten years. They have thrown away a lot of food, paid their suppliers too little, and used too much plastic in their packaging, harming the environment. But now they are paying attention. Because shoppers are upset about plastic waste, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have signed an agreement to change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

Now, she is one of the few people in the world to climb the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and she is the first person to use a hula hoop on each mountain. She does this to help women and girls in her country, where they are often told not to do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

Families were big, and their children grew up and had their own children. But in the 1960s, birth control became more available. Since then, the average number of babies per woman around the world has dropped from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: If we understand that people can have different ideas and ways of behaving, we can avoid misunderstandings. However, we must also remember that using cultural stereotypes can hurt good business relationships. Our national culture can affect how we think and act. But we are also influenced by our region, our community, our age, our gender, our company culture, and our own experiences. We should keep these differences in mind, but we should not label everyone from one country in the same way.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. If one of these medium-sized asteroids comes near Earth, it could be very dangerous.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

The book has won many prizes and is now in 41 languages. Martel’s father was a government worker who moved a lot, so Martel lived as a child in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After my parental leave, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I talked with my boss, and we agreed that I would work only three days a week. Because I work fewer days, my pay is much lower. But I have a problem. My work did not get smaller. I still have to finish five days of work in only three days, and I earn less money for it.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with people in other countries. Most business people use English, but each culture has its own way of speaking and acting. If we do not understand these cultural rules, we can judge others unfairly and make mistakes. This can stop good communication. Below are three simple areas where business manners differ around the world. They can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, we start to see early signs of people living together. One sign is paintings on cave walls. We do not know how this is linked to language. Human brains did not suddenly grow larger, but people became more clever and life became more complicated. Did speaking language help their brains grow? Or did smarter brains create language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate:
Many big supermarkets have had problems in the last ten years. People say they do wrong things. They throw away a lot of food. They pay their suppliers too little. Their plastic packages make too much trash and hurt the environment.

Customers are now angry about the plastic waste. Because of this, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have made a promise. They will change their packaging and use less plastic.
