Now supermarkets and grocers are starting to listen. Because customers are angry about the large amount of plastic waste, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have signed a promise. They say they will change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
When Wasfia Nazreen was a little girl, she saw a visitor in Bangladesh playing with a hula hoop. Wasfia wanted to try, but she only watched. Many people in her country thought girls should not use hula hoops or ride bicycles.  

Today, Wasfia is a famous mountain climber. She has climbed the seven highest mountains in the world, including Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on the top of each mountain.  

She does this to give strength and hope to women and girls in Bangladesh, where many people still tell them not to do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate:
These results show that Girox Foods should care more about its people.  
We should let workers choose flexible working hours.  
We can also let them work from different places, for example from home.  

Managers should give workers new and interesting tasks.  
They should say “thank you” and praise workers for good work.  

Girox Foods should spend more money on training.  
The training should help workers talk well with people from other cultures.  

All these ideas will make the workplace better and help everyone do their best work.

This will help create a positive workplace where employees can do their best.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, new machines and better medicine helped more children stay alive. Because of this, the world population grew very fast. Many families were big. Their children grew up and also had many babies. In the 1960s, birth control became easy to get. After that, women had fewer babies. The world average fell from about six babies for each woman to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: When we know that people from other cultures may act in different ways, we can avoid confusion. But we must not use stereotypes. Stereotypes can damage business relationships. Our country is only one part of who we are. We are also shaped by our region, our friends, our age, our gender, our company’s way of working, and our own life stories. So remember these possible differences, but do not put everyone from one country in the same box.

So, keep these possible differences in mind, but do not use them to label all people from one country.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. When you listen to “Born in the USA,” you can hear that these stories still matter today.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate:
Scientists want to know how our genes help our brain and language.  
They ask: Did some genes change and give people the power to speak?  

They found one gene that changed a very long time ago, between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago.  
This change seems to help us move our mouth and face when we speak.  

Monkeys have almost the same gene, but it did not change in them.  

We still do not know how much genes help language, but maybe we will find the answer in our DNA one day.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

So, these middle-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they come near Earth.

Suzanne says that the two things start to merge together in a disturbing way and the idea for The Hunger Games came to her.

She only saw 'reality' shows with young people competing for a million dollars and news about the war. Suzanne says these two things mixed together in an unsettling way, giving her the idea for The Hunger Games.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

The book is by Canadian writer Yann Martel. It came out in 2001. Since then, it has sold more than seven million copies around the world. It has won many awards and has been translated into 41 languages. Martel's father worked as a diplomat, and Martel lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico when he was a child.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After my parental leave, I wanted to be with my children more before they start school. I talked to my boss, and we agreed that I will work three days a week. This means I earn less money because I work fewer days. But I see that I still have the same amount of work! I do five days of work in only three days and earn less money.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Many businesses today work with people from different countries. Most people in business use English, but business communication can be different in each culture. If we do not understand other cultures' ways, we might have problems. We could make mistakes and not understand each other. Here are three simple differences in business manners around the world. Knowing them can help when working with people from other cultures.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big supermarket chains have been accused of doing bad things in the last ten years. They have thrown away a lot of food, paid their suppliers too little, and used too much plastic for packaging. This plastic is bad for our environment. But supermarkets are starting to listen. Some of the biggest UK supermarkets now promise to change their packaging and use less plastic because people are complaining about it.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

In Bangladesh, people thought girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now, Wasfia is one of the few people to climb the Seven Summits, like Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is the first to use a hula hoop on each mountain. She does this to support women and girls in her country who are told not to do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

Big families had more children who lived and made their own families. But in the 1960s, birth control became more common. This made the average number of babies for each woman drop from six to two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Understanding that people might expect and act differently can help us avoid misunderstandings. But, it's important not to use cultural stereotypes because they can harm business relationships. Our behavior and thoughts can be shaped by the country we come from. But, we are also influenced by our region, community, age, gender, work culture, and personal experiences. We should remember that people can be different, but we should not judge everyone from one country the same way.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

We do not know yet how much genes help us speak, but one day we might find the answer in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week, but after my parental leave, I wanted more time with my children before they start school. I now do five days of work in three days, but I am paid less.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses deal with people in other countries. Many people use English as a common language, but each culture has its own style of business communication. If we do not understand our partners’ cultural habits, we can make unfair judgements. This can cause misunderstandings and communication problems. There are three main ways that business rules differ around the world. Knowing these differences can help you work better with people from other cultures.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

This plastic has hurt the environment. But now, supermarkets are paying attention. Because customers are unhappy about plastic waste, some large UK supermarkets have promised to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

She noticed a foreign child playing with it, but she did not join in because many people said girls should not use hula hoops or ride bikes. She does this to support women and girls in her country, where many people do not encourage them to do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

In the 1960s, people began to use birth control more often. As a result, the average number of babies per woman went down from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Being aware that people can have different expectations and ways of behaving can help us avoid misunderstandings. It is also important to remember that cultural stereotypes can hurt good business relationships. National cultures may shape how we think and act, but many other things also influence us, such as where we live, our friends and communities, our age and gender, our workplace, and our personal experiences. We should keep these differences in mind, but we should not treat everyone from one country in the same way.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

We still do not know exactly how much genes affect language, but the answers may be in our DNA one day.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.
candidate: NASA is making a list of smaller asteroids (space rocks) that are 140 metres wide or bigger. Experts think there are about 25,000 rocks this size. They have found and listed about 8,000 so far. This means 17,000 are still not on the list. In 2013, a smaller rock, only 19 metres wide, exploded over the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia and hurt 1,200 people. So rocks that are 140 metres wide could be very dangerous if they come close to Earth.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

Do people welcome them, or do they think the animals are dangerous and a problem?

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In some cases, this could happen because inferior-quality material was used in the construction, or because of a defect in a key piece of the bridge. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.

Sometimes the builders used poor materials, or an important part of the bridge had a problem. source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. When I came back from leave to care for my baby, I wanted more time with my children before they start school. I talked with my boss, and we agreed that I would work only three days a week. Because of this, I now get less pay; I am only paid for the days I work. But my amount of work did not get smaller. I am doing five days of work in just three days, and I earn much less.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many companies work with people in other countries. Many business people use English, but each culture has its own special way to talk and act at work. If we do not know these rules, we can judge others unfairly. We can also have misunderstandings and poor communication. Below are three simple points about different business manners around the world. These ideas can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate: From 100,000 to 50,000 years ago, we start to see early signs of human life. One clear sign is cave paintings. We do not know how these pictures are linked to language. Human brains did not suddenly become bigger, but people did become smarter and their lives became more complex. Did using language make their brains grow and change, or did smarter brains create language first?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big supermarkets were criticised for bad actions in the last ten years. They threw away a lot of food. They paid their suppliers too little. They also used too much plastic in their packets, and this plastic harmed the environment. But now supermarkets and food shops are starting to listen. People are angry about all the plastic rubbish from packaging. Because of this, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have joined a new agreement. They promise to change their packaging and use less plastic.

They promise to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
Wasfia Nazreen first saw a hula hoop when she was a young girl in Bangladesh. She watched a child from another country play with it. At that time, many people in Bangladesh thought girls should not use hula hoops or ride bicycles, so Wasfia only watched.

Years later, Wasfia became very strong. She climbed the Seven Summits, the tallest mountains on each continent, such as Everest and Kilimanjaro. Very few people have done this. On each mountain top, she also used a hula hoop. She is the first person to hula-hoop on all seven peaks.

Wasfia does this to give courage and hope to women and girls in her country. She wants to show that girls can do sports too.

candidate:

Today, Wasfia is one of the very few people who have climbed all Seven Summits, including Mount Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on the top of each mountain. She does this to give strength and confidence to women and girls in Bangladesh, where society often tells them not to play sport.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: From these results, we suggest Girox Foods use a style that cares more about people. To do this, we should find ways to give workers more flexible hours and let them work in places they choose. Managers should look for different ways to give staff new and interesting tasks. They should also give more praise and thanks for the work staff do. We should spend more money on training, especially in social skills and in talking with people from other cultures. This will help create a happy workplace where everyone can do their best.

We should also spend more money on training, especially in social skills and communication between cultures. These steps will help create a positive workplace where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, better machines and better health care meant fewer children died. Because of this, the number of people in the world grew very fast. Big families had many children who lived to become adults and later had their own children. But after the 1960s, women could more easily use ways to stop having babies. Since then, the average number of babies each woman has went down from six to only two.

candidate: In the past 200 years, better technology and better health care helped more children stay alive. This made the world’s population grow quickly. Large families had many children, and most of these children grew up and started their own families. In the 1960s, birth control became easier to get, so women began to have fewer babies. The world average went down from about six babies per woman to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: If we know that people can think and act differently, we can avoid communication problems. But we must also remember that cultural stereotypes can hurt business relationships. Our country can influence how we act and think. However, many other things shape us too: the place we live, the groups we belong to, our age, our gender, our company culture, and our own life experiences. Therefore, we should keep these differences in mind, but we should not judge every person from a country in the same way.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. It doesn't surprise me at all. This is a man who tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves and, when you listen to Born in the USA, those stories are as relevant today as they ever were.

When you listen to his song “Born in the USA”, you can hear that these stories are still important today.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate:
Scientists still have many questions about how our genes help the brain and language grow. Some ask: Did a change in our genes give people the ability to speak?

Researchers found one gene that changed a long time ago—about 200,000 to 100,000 years in the past. This change seems to help us talk and move our mouths and faces when we speak. Monkeys have almost the same gene, but their gene did not change like this.

We do not yet know exactly how much genes affect language. Maybe one day we will find the full answer by studying our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

Because a 19-meter space rock blew up above a city in Russia in 2013 and hurt 1,200 people, these medium-sized space rocks could be very dangerous if they come close to Earth.

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

Martel's father worked for the government in other countries, so he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico when he was a child."

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

These can help you when you work with people from other cultures.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

Because people are unhappy about too much plastic, some big UK supermarkets agree to use less plastic in things used to wrap food, like bags and boxes.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

She does this to help women and girls in her country where people say no to them doing sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: We need to know more about how people from different places think and act. This can help us avoid problems in understanding each other. But, it is very important to remember that ideas about people from other places can be bad for making friends in business. The cultures of countries can change how we act and think. But, we also change because of where we live, our friends, age, gender, workplace habits, and what we have done in life. We should remember these differences, but we should not judge people quickly based on their country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

However, supermarkets are now paying attention to these problems. Because people are angry about all the plastic waste, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK have made a promise. They will change their packaging and reduce the amount of plastic they use.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

At that time, in Bangladesh, it was thought that girls shouldn’t play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now, Wasfia is a very special person. She has climbed the highest mountains in the world, like Mount Everest and Mount Kilimanjaro. She is the first person to hula-hoop on top of each of these mountains. She does this to encourage girls and women in Bangladesh to play sports, because in her country, it’s not common for girls to play sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.

It would also be good to help employees develop their skills, especially in understanding and working with people from different cultures. This could help create a better place for everyone to do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: Over the last 200 years, new technology and better healthcare helped fewer babies die young. This meant more people were born, and families often had many children. However, in the 1960s, it became easier for people to use birth control. Because of this, the average number of babies a woman has in her life has gone down from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Understanding that people might have different ideas about what is normal and how they behave can help us avoid misunderstandings. However, it’s important to remember that making assumptions about people based on their country can be harmful to building good business relationships. People’s behavior is influenced by many things, such as where they come from, their friends, their age, their gender, the company they work for, and their own experiences. So, it’s best to keep these differences in mind, but not to judge individuals based on their nationality.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it didn’t change in the same way. We don’t know yet exactly how much genes affect language, but maybe we will find the answers in our DNA someday.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

This small asteroid hurt 1,200 people. So these bigger asteroids would be very dangerous if they come close to Earth.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with people from other countries. Most business people speak English, but each culture has different ways of doing business. If you don't understand how people from other cultures do business, you might make mistakes. You might not understand them correctly, or you might think bad things about them. Here are three important differences in business rules around the world. These can help you when you work with someone from a different culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

Did using language make their brains grow better? Or did their better brains start to make language? We still don't know.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: In the last ten years, many big supermarket companies have been criticized for doing bad things. They have thrown away lots of food, they have not paid their suppliers enough money, and they have used too much plastic for packaging. This plastic waste has hurt our environment. But now supermarkets are starting to listen and do something about it. Many customers are angry about all the plastic waste from packaging. So some of the biggest UK supermarkets have agreed to a plan. They promise to change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

Now Wasfia is older and she has climbed seven very high mountains around the world, including Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is one of very few people to do this. She is also the first person to play with a hula hoop on top of each mountain. She did this to help women and girls in her country. In Bangladesh, people often say that women and girls should not do sports, but Wasfia wants to change this.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. The company should spend more money to help workers learn new things, especially how to talk well with different people. This will help workers feel happy and do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology and medicine got better. This meant fewer children died when they were young. Because of this, the population grew very fast. Big families had many children who lived to become adults. These adults then had their own children. But in the 1960s, people could get contraception more easily. Contraception helps people control how many babies they have. Because of this, women around the world now have fewer babies. Before, women had about six babies each. Now, women have about two babies each.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: It is good to know that people from different countries may think and act differently. This can help us talk to each other better and avoid problems. But we must be careful. We should not think that all people from one country are the same. This is not true and can make business relationships bad. Yes, the country where someone comes from can change how they think and act. But many other things are also important. For example, what part of the country they are from, what groups they belong to, how old they are, if they are a man or woman, what their company is like, and what has happened to them in their life. So we should remember that people can be different, but we should not put all people from one country in the same group.

The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.

These include the area we come from, the communities we belong to, our age and gender, our company culture, and our personal experiences. Therefore, we should keep this knowledge about cultural differences in our minds, but we should not use it to judge all people from one country in the same way.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but their gene did not change in the same way. We still don't know how much genes affect language, but maybe one day we will find the answers by studying our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. candidate: I used to work five days every week. But after I had a baby and took time off, I decided I wanted to spend more time with my children. I wanted to be with them before they go to school. I talked to my boss about this. We agreed that I would work only three days each week. This meant I would get less money too. My pay went down because I work fewer days. But I saw a problem. My work did not become less! I still have the same amount of work to do. Now I do five days of work in only three days. But I get much less money for it!

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

I talked to my boss about this. We agreed that I could work only three days a week instead of five days. This meant I would get much less money because I work fewer days. But I found a problem. I still have the same amount of work to do! Now I do the same work as before, but in only three days. I work the same amount but get much less money for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate:
Today, many businesses work with people from other countries. Most business people use English to talk to each other. But people from different cultures have different ways of doing business. They have different rules about how to be polite and how to communicate.

If we don't understand these cultural differences, we might make mistakes. We might think bad things about people that are not true. We might not understand each other well. This can cause problems when we try to work together.

Here are three important differences in business manners around the world. These tips can help you when you work with someone from a different culture.

Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Most business today happens between different countries. Many business people around the world use English to communicate. However, the way people communicate in business can be very different from one culture to another. When we do not understand the customs and ways of doing business in other cultures, we might judge people unfairly. This can cause confusion and problems when we try to communicate. Here are three main areas where business behavior is different around the world. Understanding these differences can help you when you work with people from other cultures.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate:
Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, we can see the first signs that early humans were becoming more civilized. We know this because of cave paintings they made. But no one knows how this connects to language. 

People's brains did not suddenly become bigger during this time. However, humans did become smarter and could do more complex things. 

We do not know why this happened. Did using language help their brains grow and develop? Or did their brains become better first, and then they started to create language? No one is sure about the answer.

We do not know the answer.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big supermarket companies have been criticized for doing bad things in the last ten years. They have thrown away tons of food. They have paid their suppliers too little money. They have used too much plastic in their packaging. This has hurt our environment. But supermarkets and food stores are now starting to pay attention to these problems. More and more customers are angry about the large amounts of plastic waste from plastic packaging. Because of this, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have agreed to a plan. They promise to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
When Wasfia Nazreen was a young girl, she saw a foreign child playing with a hula hoop in Bangladesh. Wasfia wanted to play too, but she could only watch. In her country, people believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes.

Now Wasfia is older and does amazing things. She climbed the Seven Summits - these are the highest mountains on each continent, like Everest and Kilimanjaro. Very few people in the world have done this. Wasfia also did something special - she played with a hula hoop on top of each mountain. She was the first person to do this.

Why did she do this? She wanted to help women and girls in her country. In Bangladesh, many people think women and girls should not do sports. Wasfia wants to change this and make women feel stronger and more confident.

Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world who has climbed the Seven Summits. These are the highest mountains on each continent, including Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is the first person to use a hula hoop on top of each mountain. She did this to help women and girls feel stronger and more confident. She wants to help them in a country that does not encourage women to do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate:
We looked at the problems and found some answers. We think Girox Foods should care more about their workers. Here are some ideas:

- Give workers more flexible hours. This means they can choose when to start and finish work.
- Let workers work from home or other places they like.
- Managers should give workers interesting tasks and say "good job" when they do well.
- The company should spend money to help workers learn new skills. Workers need to learn how to talk better with different people.

These changes will make workers happy. When workers are happy, they do better work.

Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: Based on what we found, we suggest that Girox Foods should focus more on people when managing the company. We should look for ways to give employees more flexible work hours. We should also think about letting employees work from places they choose. Managers need to find different ways to make work interesting for staff. They should give more positive feedback and recognize the good work that employees do. The company should spend more money on training programs. These programs should focus on social skills and communication between different cultures. This will help create a good workplace where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, better technology and healthcare helped more children live longer. This caused the world's population to grow very fast. Big families had many children, and most of these children lived to become adults and had their own children. But in the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. Because of this, women around the world started having fewer babies. The average number went down from six babies per woman to only two babies per woman.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
Knowing about different expectations and behavior can help us avoid misunderstanding each other. But we must remember that cultural stereotypes can hurt business relationships. 

National cultures may change how we behave and think. But many other things also influence us. These include where we live, what groups we join, our age, if we are male or female, our company culture, and our personal life experiences.

We should keep knowledge about cultural differences in our minds. But we should not use this knowledge to put all people from one country into the same group. Each person is different.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Scientists found a gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This gene seems to help with speaking and how our brains control our mouth and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but their gene did not change like ours did. We don't know yet how much genes affect language, but maybe one day we will find the answers in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

It hurt 1,200 people. These middle-sized asteroids would be very dangerous if they come close to Earth.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.
candidate: Some bridges fall down and no one knows why at first. Engineers must study the bridge carefully to find out what happened. Sometimes this happens because poor materials were used to build the bridge, or because an important part of the bridge was broken or damaged. Other times, the bridge was only made to hold a certain weight, and too much weight was put on it.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days every week. But after my baby was born, I took time off work to care for my baby. When I went back to work, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they go to school. I talked to my boss about this. We decided I would work only three days every week. This means I get much less money now because I work fewer days. But I found a problem! I still have to do the same amount of work as before. Now I do five days of work in only three days, but I get much less money for it!

I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

I still have the same amount of work to do! Now I do five days of work in only three days, but I get much less money for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with people from other countries. Most business people use English to talk to each other. But different countries have different ways of doing business. If we don't understand these differences, we might think wrong things about people. We might not understand each other well. Here are three important differences in business behavior around the world. These will help you when you work with people from other countries.

Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

However, the way people do business can be very different in each culture. When we don't understand how business works in other cultures, we can make mistakes. We might judge people unfairly or misunderstand them. Communication can also go wrong. Here are three main differences in business behavior around the world. These tips can help you when you work with people from different cultures.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, we can see early humans making art. For example, they painted pictures on cave walls. But no one knows how this connects to language. Human brains did not get bigger quickly. But humans became smarter and could do more difficult things. Did using language make their brains grow? Or did their better brains start making language? We do not know.

Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, we can see the first signs that early humans were becoming more civilized. For example, they made paintings on cave walls. But no one knows how this connects to language development. Human brains did not suddenly grow bigger during this time. However, humans did become more complex and smarter. Did using language help their brains develop better? Or did their more advanced brains start creating language? We don't know the answer.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big supermarket companies have had problems in the last ten years. People say they have done bad things. They have thrown away lots of food. They have not paid enough money to their suppliers. They have used too much plastic for packaging. This plastic waste is bad for our environment. But now supermarkets are starting to listen. Many people do not like the plastic waste from packaging. So some of the biggest UK supermarkets have made a promise. They will change their packaging. They will use less plastic waste.

They have used too much plastic in their packaging, and this has hurt the environment. But supermarkets and food stores are now starting to pay attention to these problems. Customers are angry about the large amounts of plastic waste from packaging. Because of this anger, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have agreed to a plan. They promise to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
Wasfia Nazreen saw a hula hoop for the first time when she was a young girl. She saw a foreign child playing with one in Bangladesh, her home country. Wasfia could only watch. She could not play with it. In her country, people believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes.

Now Wasfia has climbed the Seven Summits. These are the highest mountains in the world, like Everest and Kilimanjaro. Very few people have climbed all of them. She is the first person to use a hula hoop on each mountain top.

Why did she do this? She wanted to help women and girls in her country. In Bangladesh, women and girls are told they should not do sports. Wasfia wants to change this.

Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak.
