Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world who has climbed the Seven Summits. These are the highest mountains on each continent, including Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on top of each mountain. She did this to give power and confidence to women and girls in her country. In Bangladesh, women and girls are often told not to do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate:
Based on what we found, we think Girox Foods should change how it manages people. The company should care more about its workers. Here are our ideas:

- Give workers more flexible working hours
- Let workers choose where they work from
- Managers should find different ways to challenge their workers
- Give workers more praise and say "thank you" for good work
- Spend more money on training workers, especially training about talking to people from different cultures

These changes will help create a better place to work. When workers are happy, they do their best work.

Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: Based on what we found, we suggest that Girox Foods should focus more on caring for their workers. We should look at ways to give employees more flexible work hours and let them work from places they choose. Managers need to find different ways to give workers interesting tasks and praise them more for their good work. The company should also spend more money on training, especially to help employees communicate better with people from different backgrounds. This will help create a better workplace where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, better technology and healthcare helped more children live longer. This made the world's population grow very fast. Big families had many children, and these children lived to become adults and have their own children. But in the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. Because of this, women around the world now have fewer babies. Before, women had about six babies each. Now, women have about two babies each.

candidate: In the past 200 years, better technology and healthcare helped more children live longer. This caused the population to grow very quickly. Large families had many children who lived to become adults and then had their own children. But in the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. Because of this, women around the world now have fewer babies. The average number went down from six babies per woman to only two babies per woman.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
Knowing about different expectations and behaviors can help us avoid misunderstandings. But we must remember that cultural stereotypes can hurt business relationships. 

National cultures may affect how we behave and think. But other things also influence us. These include where we live, our communities, our age, our gender, our company culture, and our personal experiences.

We should keep knowledge about cultural differences in our minds. But we should not use this knowledge to put all people from one country into the same group.

So we should keep knowledge about differences in mind, but we should not use it to put all people from one country into the same group.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate: Scientists want to know more about how genes affect our brain and language. Are there genes that changed and gave humans the ability to speak? Scientists found a gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This gene seems to help with speaking and how our brain controls our mouth and face. Monkeys have the same gene, but their gene did not change like ours did. We don't know yet how much genes affect language, but maybe one day we will find the answers by studying our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.
candidate: Now NASA is working to find and record smaller asteroids. These asteroids are 140 metres wide or bigger. Scientists think there are about 25,000 asteroids of this size. So far, they have found about 8,000 of them. This means 17,000 asteroids are still missing. In 2013, a small asteroid that was only 19 metres wide exploded over a city called Chelyabinsk in Russia. This small asteroid hurt 1,200 people. So these bigger asteroids would be very dangerous if they came close to Earth.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. Every year one boy and one girl aged 12 to 18 are chosen from each district by lottery to compete in a battle in which only one person can survive. The chosen teenagers are called "tributes". The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.

Each year, they choose one boy and one girl from each district. These young people are between 12 and 18 years old. They choose them by lottery - this means they pick names randomly. These young people are called "tributes". The tributes have to fight each other. Only one person can live at the end. Everyone in the country must watch this on TV.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. But in recent years, the world's press has been full of reports of wild animals coming into cities in bigger and bigger numbers. There have been bears in Vancouver parks, leopards on the streets of Mumbai and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when bigger animals come into our cities? Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?
candidate: You can see many small animals like birds, mice and bugs in cities and towns. This is normal. But now, there are more and more big wild animals coming to cities too. People have seen bears in parks in Vancouver. There were leopards walking on streets in Mumbai. Wild pigs have come into gardens in Berlin. What happens when these big animals come to our cities? Do people like them? Or do people think they are dangerous?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PHAs, none of which are expected to be a threat in the next one hundred years. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.

They have made a map of 1,400 of these rocks. NASA thinks these rocks will not hit Earth in the next 100 years. NASA has computers and machines that can watch these rocks. They can tell us if a rock might hit Earth. If this happens, NASA has two ways to stop the rock from hitting our planet.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

When Martel was a child, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

Sometimes this happens because the materials used to build the bridge were not good enough. Sometimes an important part of the bridge was broken. Other times, the bridge was made to carry only a certain weight, and too much weight was put on it.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days every week. Then I had a baby and took time off work. After that, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they go to school. I talked to my boss about this. We decided I would work only three days each week. This means I get less money now because I work fewer days. But I have a problem. I still have the same amount of work to do! Now I do five days of work in only three days, but I get much less money for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate:
Today, many people do business with other countries. Most business people around the world speak English. But different countries have different ways of doing business. People from different places have different ideas about how to be polite in business.

If you don't understand how people from other countries like to do business, there can be problems. You might think bad things about them that are not true. You might not understand each other. You might have arguments.

Here are three important differences in business manners around the world. These will help you when you work with people from other countries.

Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

If we don't understand the cultural rules and practices of our business partners, this can lead to unfair opinions, confusion and problems in communication. Here are three basic areas where business manners around the world are different. These could help you when you next work with someone from a different culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate: A very long time ago, between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, people started to make art. We can see this art on the walls of caves. But we don't know how this connects to language - the way people talk to each other. People's brains did not get bigger at this time. But people became smarter and could do more difficult things. We have a question: Did using language make people's brains better? Or did better brains make people start using language? We don't know the answer.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: In the last ten years, many big supermarket companies have had problems. People say they do bad things. They throw away lots of food. They don't pay their suppliers enough money. They use too much plastic for packaging. This plastic is bad for our environment. But now supermarkets are starting to listen. Many customers are angry about all the plastic waste. So some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK have made a promise. They want to change their packaging. They want to use less plastic and make less waste.

But supermarkets and food shops are starting to pay attention to these problems. More and more customers are angry about the large amounts of plastic waste from plastic packaging. Because of this, some of the largest UK supermarkets have agreed to a plan. They promise to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate: Wasfia Nazreen first saw a hula hoop when she was a young girl. A foreign child was visiting her country, Bangladesh, and was playing with one. Wasfia could only watch because in her country, people believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia has climbed the Seven Summits - the highest mountains in the world like Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is one of very few people to do this. She is also the first person to play with a hula hoop on top of each mountain. She did this to help women and girls in her country feel strong. In Bangladesh, many people think women and girls should not do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: We think Girox Foods should change how they manage their workers. The company should care more about people. Here are some ideas: First, give workers more flexible hours - this means workers can choose when to start and finish work. Second, let workers work from home or other places they like. Managers should also give workers new and interesting tasks. They should say "good job" more often when workers do well. The company should also spend more money on training workers. Workers need to learn how to talk better with people from different countries and cultures. All these changes will help workers feel happy and do their best work.

Managers need to think about different ways to challenge our staff and give more positive feedback and recognition for the work they do. Spending more money on professional development, especially in the area of social and communication between different cultures, could also help create a positive environment for employees to do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology and health got better. This meant fewer children died when they were young. Because of this, the number of people grew very fast. Big families had many children. These children lived to become adults and had their own children. But in the 1960s, people could get birth control more easily. Now, women around the world have fewer babies. Before, women had six babies on average. Now they have only two babies on average.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology got better and people became healthier. This meant that fewer children died when they were young, so the population grew very quickly. Large families had many children, and more of these children lived to become adults and have their own children. But in the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. Because of this, the average number of babies that women have around the world has gone down. It went from six babies per woman to only two babies per woman.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: We should know that people from different countries might have different ideas about how to act and what to expect. This can help us understand each other better when we work together. But we must be careful. We should not think that all people from one country are the same. This is wrong and can make business relationships bad. It's true that the country we come from can change how we think and act. But other things are also important. Where we live, our friends, how old we are, if we are men or women, our company, and what has happened to us in our life - all these things make us different. So we should remember that people can be different, but we should not put all people from one country in the same group. Each person is different.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing about possible differences in what people expect and how they behave can help us avoid problems when we communicate. But it is very important to remember that ideas about cultures can be harmful when we try to build good business relationships. National cultures may influence how we behave and think, but many other things also affect us. These include the area we come from, the groups we spend time with, our age and gender, our company culture, and our personal experiences in life. So we should keep knowledge about possible differences in our minds, but we should not use it to put all people from one country into the same group.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Scientists found one gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This gene seems to help with speaking and how our brains control our mouth and face. Monkeys have the same gene, but their gene did not change. We do not know yet how much genes help with language, but maybe one day we will find the answers in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

These asteroids could be dangerous if they come close to Earth.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

Or are they dangerous or a problem?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PHAs, none of which are expected to be a threat in the next one hundred years. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.

Scientists don’t think any of them will hit Earth in the next 100 years. NASA can track these rocks with technology and guess when they might be dangerous. If they think there’s a problem, they could send rockets to protect us.

source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. Suzanne says that the two things start to merge together in a disturbing way and the idea for The Hunger Games came to her.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

It has also won many awards and has been translated into 41 different languages. Yann Martel grew up in many countries, including Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico, because his father was a diplomat.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work for five days a week. When I had my children, I wanted to spend more time with them before they went to school. I talked to my boss, and we agreed to work only three days a week. This meant I earned less money, because I get paid based on how many days I work. But now, I have to do the same amount of work as before, but I’m paid much less!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with people in different countries. Most business people use English, but the way we talk and behave in business can be different depending on where someone is from. If we don’t understand how people from other cultures behave, we might make mistakes or have misunderstandings. Here are three important things to know about how people do business in different countries, which can help you when you work with someone new.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

Or did their cleverer brains help them start talking?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Some big shops like supermarkets have faced problems in the last ten years. People have said they have done some bad things, like throwing away lots of food, not paying workers enough, and using too much plastic in their packaging. This plastic has hurt the environment. However, these shops are now paying attention. Because many people were unhappy about all the plastic waste, some big supermarkets in the UK have made a promise. They will change their packaging and try to use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate: Wasfia Nazreen first saw a hula hoop when she was a child. She saw a girl from another country playing with it in Bangladesh. At that time, in Bangladesh, it was not usual for girls to play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now, Wasfia is a very special person. She has climbed the highest mountains in the world, like Mount Everest and Mount Kilimanjaro. She is the first person to hula hoop on top of each mountain. She does this to help girls and women in her country, who are not encouraged to play sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: We think Girox Foods should be more friendly to its workers. This means we could try to give workers more flexible hours, like different start and finish times. Also, we should think about letting workers work from where they choose. Managers should try to help workers and praise their good work. It would be good to spend more money on training workers, especially in how to talk to people from different cultures. This will help workers feel happy and do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: For the last 200 years, new inventions and better healthcare helped children live longer. This meant more babies were born. Families often had many children, and those children grew up and had their own children too. However, in the 1960s, it became easier for people to use birth control. Because of this, the average number of babies a woman has in her life has gone down from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: It’s important to understand that people might have different ideas about things and act differently. This can help us avoid misunderstandings. However, it’s also important to remember that stereotypes about cultures can be bad for building good business relationships. We are all different because of where we come from, our age, our gender, and our experiences. We shouldn’t use stereotypes to judge people from an entire country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

This gene changed a long time ago, about 200,000 to 100,000 years ago. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it didn’t change in the same way. We don’t know yet how much genes help us learn to speak. Maybe one day, we will find the answers in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

However, I’m still doing the same amount of work as before! I’m working five days’ worth of work in just three days, but I’m earning much less money.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Many businesses now work with people in other countries. Most business people use English, but the way people talk and behave in business can be different depending on where they are from. If you don't understand the rules of how people behave in business in different countries, you might make wrong judgements, have misunderstandings, or communication might not work well. Here are three important things to remember when working with people from different cultures to help you be successful.

Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

Or did their smarter brains start to create language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big shops have been criticized for doing bad things in the last ten years. They have thrown away lots of food, paid workers less money, and made too much plastic waste in their packaging. This has hurt our environment. But now, the shops are starting to pay attention. Because people are angry about all the plastic waste, some of the biggest shops in the UK have promised to change their packaging and reduce the amount of plastic they use.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

In Bangladesh, it was thought that girls shouldn’t play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Wasfia didn't want to play at first. Now, Wasfia is one of the few people in the world who has climbed the highest mountains, like Mount Everest and Mount Kilimanjaro. She is the first person to hula-hoop on top of each mountain. She climbs these mountains to help girls and women in her country, where it’s not common for them to play sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.

Managers should also find ways to encourage workers and say thank you for good work. It would be good to help workers learn more about other people and cultures. This could make workers feel happier and do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: For the last 200 years, new technology and better healthcare have helped fewer children die young. This meant more people were born. Big families had more children who grew up and had their own children too. However, in the 1960s, it became easier for people to use birth control. Because of this, the average number of babies a woman has each time she has a baby has gone down from six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.

So, we should keep these differences in mind, but not use them to judge people from entire countries.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

We don’t know yet how much our genes affect language, but maybe we will find out by looking at our DNA in the future.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

Yann Martel’s father was a diplomat, and he moved to many countries as a child, including Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico.

However, I’m still doing the same amount of work as before, but I’m getting paid much less!

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work a normal five-day week. But after I had my baby, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they started school. I talked to my boss, and we agreed to work fewer days – just three days a week. This meant I got paid less money, because I was paid based on the number of days I worked. However, I’ve found that I’m actually doing the same amount of work as before, but I’m getting paid much less!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with people in other countries. Most business people around the world use English, but how people talk and behave in business can be very different depending on their culture. If you don't understand how people from another country do things in business, it can cause problems like unfair decisions, misunderstandings, and trouble talking. Here are three important differences in how people behave in business around the world that can help you when you work with someone from a different culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

People’s brains didn’t get much bigger, but they became more clever and more complicated. Did talking help their brains grow? Or did their cleverer brains start to make language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Some big shops like supermarkets have been criticised for bad things they have done in the last ten years. They have thrown away lots of food, paid their suppliers too little money, and used too much plastic in their packaging, which is bad for the environment. But now, these shops are starting to pay attention. Because people are angry about all the plastic waste, some of the biggest shops in the UK have made a promise. They will change their packaging and use less plastic.

This plan means they will change how they package things and reduce the amount of plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate: Wasfia Nazreen first saw a hula hoop when she was a child. She saw a girl from another country playing with it in Bangladesh. In Bangladesh, it was not normal for girls to play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now, Wasfia is one of the few people who has climbed the highest mountains in the world, like Mount Everest and Mount Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on top of each mountain. She does this to help girls and women in her country, where it is not common for them to play sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: Because of these results, we think Girox Foods should be more friendly to its workers. We should try to give workers more choices about when and where they work. Managers should find ways to encourage workers and say thank you for their good work. It would also be good to help workers learn new skills, especially about working with people from different cultures. This could help workers do their best work in a happy place.

This could help workers do their best work and create a happy workplace.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: For the last 200 years, new technology and better healthcare helped fewer children die young, so the number of people in the world grew quickly. Big families had many children who lived to be adults and had their own children too. However, in the 1960s, it became easier for people to stop having babies. Now, on average, women have about two babies in the world.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: If we understand that people might have different ideas and ways of behaving, we can avoid misunderstandings. However, it’s important to remember that ideas about different cultures can be harmful when building good business connections. We are all different because of where we live, our friends, our age, our gender, the company we work for, and our own experiences. So, we should remember these differences, but not use them to judge people from a whole country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate: Scientists are looking at how genes affect our brains and how we learn to speak. They think there might be a special gene that helped people start speaking a long time ago – about 200,000 to 100,000 years ago. This gene is similar to one found in monkeys, but the monkeys didn’t change it. We don’t know exactly how much genes affect our language yet, but scientists might find the answers in our DNA in the future.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

These middle-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they come near Earth.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. But in recent years, the world's press has been full of reports of wild animals coming into cities in bigger and bigger numbers. There have been bears in Vancouver parks, leopards on the streets of Mumbai and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when bigger animals come into our cities? Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

Are they welcome, or do people think they are dangerous or a problem?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

Since then, it has sold more than seven million copies around the world, won many prizes, and been translated into 41 languages. Yann Martel’s father was a diplomat, so Yann lived in places like Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico when he was young.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

They have also used too much plastic in their packaging, which has hurt the environment. Now, supermarkets are starting to pay attention. People are angry about all the plastic waste. Because of this, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have promised to change their packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

She does this to encourage women and girls in her country, where many people do not support them doing sport.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. This will make employees feel happy and do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology and health care improved. This meant fewer young children died, so families became very large. These children grew up and had their own children. But in the 1960s, contraception became easier to get. As a result, the average number of babies per woman fell from about six to two.

Large families had many children who survived into adulthood and started families of their own. source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: It is important to know that people in different cultures can have different expectations and ways of behaving. This can help us avoid problems when we talk to each other. But we must also remember that thinking everyone from one culture is the same can hurt business relationships. Our country can affect how we act and think, but so can the place we live, our friends, our age, our gender, our workplace and our own experiences. We should keep these differences in mind, but we should not say that everyone from one nation is the same.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not change in the same way. We still do not know how important genes are for language. Maybe someday, we will find the answers in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

Rocks that are 140 metres wide could be even more dangerous if they come near Earth.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

Do people like them, or do people think they are dangerous or a problem?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PHAs, none of which are expected to be a threat in the next one hundred years. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.

If one ever looks dangerous, experts have two ways to try to push it away.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

I still must do five days of work in just three days, and I earn much less money for it!

candidate: Today, a great deal of business takes place between people in different countries. Many professionals use English to speak to each other, but the style and expectations of business communication can still vary a lot from one culture to another. If we do not understand the usual customs of our business partners, we may judge them unfairly, misunderstand them, or even stop communicating well. Below are three main areas where business etiquette differs around the world; knowing them can help you when you next work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Or did their more complex brains start producing language?

Their brains did not suddenly become bigger, yet people became more clever. Did speaking words help their brains grow? Or did their better brains create language first?

So which came first? Did the use of language help the brain develop, or did a more advanced brain create language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate:
Big supermarket companies have had problems. For about ten years, people say they have done bad things. They throw away a lot of food. They pay the people who give them food too little money. They use too much plastic in their packages, and this plastic hurts the environment.

Now the supermarkets are starting to listen. Many customers are angry about the plastic trash. Because of this, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have made a promise. They will change their packages and use less plastic.

Now these supermarkets and grocers are starting to pay attention. Because customers are increasingly angry about plastic waste, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed a special agreement. They promise to change how they package their products and to reduce the amount of plastic they use.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
When Wasfia Nazreen was a little girl in Bangladesh, she saw a girl from another country playing with a hula hoop. Wasfia wanted to try, but many people in Bangladesh said girls should not use hula hoops or ride bikes, so she only watched.

Years later, Wasfia became very strong. She climbed the highest mountain on each of the seven continents, for example Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is the first person to hula hoop on the top of every one of these mountains.

Wasfia does this to give courage to women and girls in Bangladesh, where many people still believe sport is not for them.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: We studied the results and have some ideas for Girox Foods. First, the company should care more about its workers. It can let people choose work hours that suit them and, if possible, work from places they like, such as home. Managers should give workers new tasks that make them think and also say “good job” often. The company should spend more money on training, especially on how to talk and work with people from other cultures. These steps can make the workplace happier and help everyone do their best.

We should also spend more money on training, especially on social and intercultural communication. These steps will help create a workplace where employees can do their best.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, better machines and better medicine helped more babies live. Because of this, the world population grew fast. Families were large, and their children grew up and had more children. In the 1960s, birth control (contraception) became easy to get. After that, women had fewer babies. On average, the number went down from six babies for each woman to only about two.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the past 200 years, better technology and health care have meant that fewer children die young. Because of this, the population grew quickly, as large families produced more children who lived to become adults and later had their own children. However, once contraception became widely available in the 1960s, the world average number of babies per woman fell from about six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing that people from different places may expect different things and act in different ways can help us avoid misunderstanding each other. But we must also remember that simple ideas about a whole group, called stereotypes, are bad for good work relationships. The way we act and think comes from many parts of our life: our country, our region, our friends and communities, our age, our gender, the company we work for, and our own life experiences. So we should keep these possible differences in mind, but we should not say that all people from one country are the same.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing that people may have different expectations and ways of behaving can help us avoid miscommunication. However, we must also remember that cultural stereotypes can harm good business relationships. Our national culture can influence how we act and think, but many other things shape us as well. These include the region we live in, the communities we belong to, our age and gender, the culture of our workplace, and our personal experiences. Therefore, we should keep these possible differences in mind, but we should not use them to label everyone from one country.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. It doesn't surprise me at all. This is a man who tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves and, when you listen to Born in the USA, those stories are as relevant today as they ever were.
candidate: Many famous singers stop making hit songs when they get older. But Bruce Springsteen is different. He is almost 70, yet he still makes new songs that go to number one and fill big stadiums. This does not surprise me. Springsteen tells strong, simple stories about people’s lives. When you listen to his song “Born in the USA,” you can hear that these stories are still important today.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate: Scientists want to know how our genes can shape our brain and our language. Did some genes change and give us the ability to speak? Researchers found one gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This change seems to help us speak and helps our brain move our mouth and face. Monkeys have almost the same gene, but their gene did not change in this way. We still do not know exactly how much genes guide language, but maybe, one day, the answer will be in our DNA—the tiny code inside every cell of our body.

Monkeys have almost the same gene, but theirs did not change in this way. We still do not know exactly how much genes shape language, but future studies of our DNA might give the answer.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

But 17,000 are still missing from the list. In 2013, a small space rock (only 19 metres wide) broke up over a city in Russia called Chelyabinsk. This hurt 1,200 people. So if the bigger rocks come near Earth, they will be very dangerous.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

When Yann was a child, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: Before, I worked five days every week. But after I had time off when my baby was born, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they go to school. I talked to my boss and we agreed that I would work only three days every week. Of course, this means I get much less money because I work fewer days. But now I see a problem! I still have the same amount of work to do. I am doing five days of work in only three days, but I get much less money for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

We might not understand each other well. Here are three important differences in business manners around the world. These can help you when you work with people from other countries.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

They have used too much plastic for food packages. This plastic is bad for our world. But now supermarkets are starting to listen. More and more customers are angry about all the plastic waste. So some of the biggest UK supermarkets have made a promise. They want to change their packages and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

She climbed seven of the world's highest mountains, like Everest and Kilimanjaro. She was the first person to use a hula hoop on top of each mountain. Why did she do this? She wants to help women and girls in her country do more sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style.
