source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology got better and people became healthier. This meant that fewer children died when they were young. So the world's population grew very quickly. Big families had many children, and these children lived to become adults. Then these adults had their own children too. But in the 1960s, people could get contraception more easily. Contraception helps people control how many babies they have. Because of this, women around the world started having fewer babies. Before, women had about six babies each. Now, women have about two babies each.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: When we know that people from different countries might act differently, we can talk to them better. But we must be careful. We should not think that all people from one country are the same. This can make our business relationships bad. Yes, the country where people come from can change how they think and act. But many other things are also important. For example, what part of the country they live in, their friends, how old they are, if they are men or women, what their company is like, and what has happened in their life. So we should remember that people can be different, but we should not put all people from one country in the same group.

Therefore, we should keep knowledge about cultural differences in the back of our minds, but we should not use this knowledge to put all people from one country into the same category.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but their gene did not change like ours did. We don't know yet how much our genes help us with language, but maybe one day we will find the answers in our DNA.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

She does this to help girls and women in her country, because they are not allowed to play sport.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

Now, on average, women have fewer babies, about two babies per woman.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: It is good to know that people might have different ideas and ways of behaving. This can help us not to make mistakes when we talk. But it is very important to remember that ideas about different countries can be bad. We are all different because of where we live, the people we know, our age, our gender, and our own experiences. We should not think of people from a country as the same as all the people in that country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not change. We don't know how much genes help us with language, but maybe we will find the answers in our DNA one day.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. If bigger rocks like these come close to Earth, they could be very dangerous.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

This can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

Big families had more children, and these children grew up and had their own kids. But in the 1960s, birth control became widely used, and the average number of children per woman went down from six to two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing that people can have different ideas and actions can help us avoid mistakes when we talk to each other. But it is important to remember that thinking all people from one culture are the same can be bad for business. Our national culture can affect how we act and think, but so can where we live, our age, gender, the groups we are part of, the companies we work for, and our life experiences. We should remember these differences, but we should not judge everyone from one country the same way.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

This change helps us speak and move our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not change. We do not know yet how much genes help with language, but maybe one day we will find out by studying our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PHAs, none of which are expected to be a threat in the next one hundred years. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate:
I used to work five days a week.
After my parental leave, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school.
I talked with my boss and asked to work less.
We agreed I would work only three days a week.
Because of this, my pay went down a lot.
I am paid pro rata. This means if I work fewer days, I get less money.
But my amount of work did not get smaller.
I am doing five days of work in only three days, and I get paid much less for it.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

Here are three basic differences in business manners around the world. They can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

Now Wasfia is one of the few people who have climbed the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. She climbed Everest and Kilimanjaro too. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on the top of each mountain. She does this to inspire women and girls in her country, where many people tell them not to do sports.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate:
Wasfia Nazreen saw a hula hoop for the first time when she was a young girl in Bangladesh. She saw a foreign child playing with one. Wasfia had to stand and watch, because in her country many people believed girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. 

Now she is one of the few people in the world who have climbed the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent, including Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on each mountain. She does this to inspire and support women and girls in a country where many people tell them not to play sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: From these results, we suggest that Girox Foods use a more people-focused management style. We should find ways to offer flexible work hours. We should also find ways to let employees work from places they choose, like home. Managers should find different ways to challenge staff. They should also give more praise and recognition for good work. We should spend more on training, especially on how to talk and work with people from different cultures. This will help create a positive workplace where employees can do their best work.

Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: Based on these findings, we suggest that Girox Foods use a way of managing that focuses more on people. We should offer flexible working hours and let employees choose where they work. Managers should give staff new challenges and more praise and recognition for their work. We should also invest more in training, especially in social skills and communication with people from different cultures. This will help create a positive workplace where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the past 200 years, technology and health care got better. Fewer children died young. This made the population grow quickly. Families were large. Many children lived to be adults and had their own children. In the 1960s, ways to stop pregnancy became easy to get. After that, the average number of babies per woman in the world fell from about six to about two.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the past 200 years, better technology and healthcare meant fewer children died young. This made the population grow quickly. Families were large, and many of those children grew up and had children of their own. But in the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. As a result, the average number of babies per woman around the world fell from about six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
Being more aware of differences in what people expect and how they act can help us avoid misunderstandings. But it is very important to remember that fixed ideas about a culture can harm good business relationships.

A person’s country can affect how they think and behave. But many other things shape us too. These include the area we come from, the groups or communities we belong to, our age and gender, the culture of our company, and our own life experiences.

So we should keep these possible differences in mind. However, we should not use them to judge or label everyone from one country as the same.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing that people may have different expectations and ways of behaving can help us avoid misunderstandings. But we must also remember that fixed ideas about cultures can harm good business relationships. A country’s culture can affect how we think and act. However, we are also influenced by our region, our community, our age and gender, our workplace culture, and our own life experiences. So we should keep these possible differences in mind, but we should not assume that all people from one country are the same.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. It doesn't surprise me at all. This is a man who tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves and, when you listen to Born in the USA, those stories are as relevant today as they ever were.
candidate: Unlike many other famous musicians, Bruce Springsteen still releases new songs that become big hits. His shows fill big stadiums. He is still very good, even in his late 60s. This does not surprise me. He tells important stories about our lives. When you listen to "Born in the USA," these stories still feel true today, just like before.

When you listen to his album Born in the USA, you can hear that these stories still matter today, just as much as before.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate: There are more questions about how genes affect the brain and language. Did some genes change and help humans speak? Scientists found a gene change that happened 200,000 to 100,000 years ago. This change seems to be connected to speaking and to how the brain moves the mouth and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but this gene did not change in them. We still do not know how much genes affect language, but maybe one day we will find the answers in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but they did not have this change. We still do not know how much genes affect language, but we may find the answers in our DNA in the future.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.
candidate: NASA is now trying to find and record smaller asteroids. These are 140 meters wide or bigger. Scientists think there are about 25,000 asteroids this size. So far, they have found about 8,000. About 17,000 are still not found. In 2013, a 19-meter asteroid exploded in the sky over Chelyabinsk, Russia. It hurt 1,200 people. So, these middle-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they enter orbit around Earth.

source: Earthquakes damage all structures, including bridges. Luckily, this kind of collapse is relatively infrequent, especially with modern bridges. Engineers have learned to design bridges in earthquake zones on areas that are much more resistant to movement.
candidate: Earthquakes can damage buildings and bridges. But bridge collapses are not common, especially with modern bridges. Engineers now design bridges in earthquake areas on ground that does not move much.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. Every year one boy and one girl aged 12 to 18 are chosen from each district by lottery to compete in a battle in which only one person can survive. The chosen teenagers are called "tributes". The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.
candidate: The Hunger Games happen once a year. The Capitol uses them to punish the districts for fighting against the Capitol in the past. Each year, one boy and one girl, ages 12 to 18, are chosen from each district. Their names are picked at random, like a lottery. They must fight until only one person stays alive. These boys and girls are called “tributes.” Everyone in the country must watch the Games on TV.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. But in recent years, the world's press has been full of reports of wild animals coming into cities in bigger and bigger numbers. There have been bears in Vancouver parks, leopards on the streets of Mumbai and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when bigger animals come into our cities? Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?
candidate: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice, and insects are common in many cities and towns. In the last few years, the news has many stories about wild animals coming into cities more and more. People have seen bears in parks in Vancouver, leopards on the streets in Mumbai, and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when big animals come into our cities? Are they welcome, or are they seen as dangerous or a problem?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PHAs, none of which are expected to be a threat in the next one hundred years. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.
candidate: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids are space rocks that can come within 7.5 million kilometers of Earth’s path around the Sun. NASA made a map of 1,400 of these rocks. None of them are expected to hit Earth in the next 100 years. With today’s technology, NASA can follow these rocks and predict if one might hit. If needed, they could use two ways to protect Earth.

source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. The only programmes she could find on TV were 'reality' programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars and news programmes about the war. Suzanne says that the two things start to merge together in a disturbing way and the idea for The Hunger Games came to her.

One kind was reality shows with young people trying to win one million dollars. The other kind was news about the war. Suzanne says these two things began to feel mixed together in a scary way. Then she got the idea for The Hunger Games.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.
candidate:
The Life of Pi is an amazing story about Pi, a teenage boy from India. His ship sinks. He gets stuck in a small lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a very dangerous tiger.

It is the third book by the Canadian writer Yann Martel. It was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies around the world. It has won many prizes and has been translated into 41 languages.

Yann Martel’s father was a diplomat, a government worker in other countries. When Yann was a child, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico.

source: Dreams of a phone call from an old friend or the death of someone close, for example, are more likely to be the result of coincidence than prophecy. And, of course, we probably choose to forget all the times we dream about such events but they don't happen.
candidate: Dreams about getting a call from an old friend, or about someone close dying, are usually just chance, not a way to tell the future. We also often forget the many times we dream these things and they do not happen.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In some cases, this could happen because inferior-quality material was used in the construction, or because of a defect in a key piece of the bridge. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.
candidate: Some bridge collapses are mysteries. Engineers find the reason only after they do a full check. Sometimes the builders used bad material. Or there was a problem in an important part of the bridge. In other cases, the bridge was made to hold only a certain weight, and not more.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate:
I used to work five days a week.
After I came back from parental leave, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school.
I talked with my boss, and we agreed that I would work only three days a week.
This meant a big cut in my pay, because I am paid only for the days I work.
After that, I saw that my amount of work did not get smaller.
I am doing five days of work in three days, but I get much less money.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After I returned from parental leave, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I talked with my boss, and we agreed that I would work three days a week. This also meant a big cut in my pay, because I am paid only for the days I work. Since then, I have seen that my amount of work has not gone down at all. I am doing five days of work in three days, but I am paid much less.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate:
Today, many businesses work across countries. Many people in business use English. But the way people communicate at work can be very different in each culture.

If we do not know other people's usual ways at work, we may think badly of them. We may also not understand each other.

Here are three simple areas where business manners are different around the world. Knowing these can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

If we do not understand other people’s customs, we may judge them unfairly, misunderstand them, and have problems communicating. Here are three basic areas where business etiquette differs around the world. Knowing these can help you the next time you work with someone from a different culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, we can see signs of early humans, like cave paintings. We do not know how this and language are connected. Brains did not suddenly become bigger, but people did more things and became more clever. Did using language make their brains grow? Or did better brains make language begin?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big supermarkets got a lot of criticism in the last 10 years. People say they did some wrong things. They wasted a lot of food. They paid their suppliers too little. They used too much plastic to wrap products, and this hurt the environment. Now supermarkets and food shops are starting to pay attention. Because many customers are unhappy about plastic waste, some of the biggest UK supermarkets agreed to a plan. The plan is to change packaging and use less plastic.

But supermarkets and grocers are starting to change. Because many customers are angry about plastic waste, some of the largest UK supermarkets have agreed to a plan to change packaging and reduce plastic waste.

When Wasfia Nazreen was a young girl, she saw a visiting foreign child in Bangladesh playing with a hula hoop. Wasfia only watched, because people in her country thought girls should not use hula hoops or ride bikes.

Now, Wasfia has climbed the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent, including Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula-hoop on each mountain. She did this to inspire and empower women and girls in a country that does not support them playing sports.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, better health care and new technology meant fewer children died young. So the population grew fast. Many families were large and had many children. Many of these children lived to be adults and had their own children. In the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. After that, the average number of babies per woman in the world went down from about six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
If we know more about the possible differences in what people expect and how they behave, we can avoid misunderstandings.
But we should not use general ideas about cultures to judge people. These ideas are called stereotypes. They can harm good work relationships.
Our national culture can change how we think and act.
But many other things also affect us: the region we come from, the community around us, our age and gender, how people do things at work, and our own life experiences.
So, remember that differences may exist.
Keep this in mind, but do not judge a person only because of their nation. See each person as a person.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Being more aware of differences in what people expect and how they act can help us avoid misunderstandings. But it is also important to remember that cultural stereotypes can harm good business relationships. National culture can affect how we think and behave. However, we are also shaped by our region, our communities, our age and gender, our workplace culture, and our own life experiences. So keep these possible differences in mind, but do not use them to label people or to assume that everyone in a country is the same.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. When you listen to Born in the USA, you can hear that these stories are still important today.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not have this change. It is still too early to know how much genes affect language. Maybe one day we will find the answers in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

This shows that these medium-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they come near Earth.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. But in recent years, the world's press has been full of reports of wild animals coming into cities in bigger and bigger numbers. Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?

Do people welcome them, or do they think these animals are dangerous or cause problems?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After my time off for my children, I wanted to spend more time with them before they start school. I talked to my boss, and we agreed I would work three days a week. Because of this, my pay went down. I am paid only for the days I work. But my work did not get smaller. Now I do five days of work in three days, and I get less money for it.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Today, many businesses work with people in other countries. Many people use English, but small differences and what people expect in business talk can be very different in each culture. If we do not understand the usual ways of the people we work with, we may judge them unfairly. We may also have misunderstandings and problems with communication. Here are three simple areas where business manners differ around the world. These ideas can help you next time you work with someone from another culture.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate:
In the last ten years, many big supermarkets did things that people say are wrong. They threw away a lot of food. They paid farmers and other sellers too little money. They used too much plastic in their packaging, like the bags and boxes around products. This hurts the environment.

But now supermarkets and food shops are starting to listen. More and more customers are angry about plastic waste. Because of this, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have signed an agreement. They promise to change their packaging and cut plastic waste.

In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

But supermarkets and grocery stores are starting to pay attention and act. Because more customers are unhappy about the large amount of plastic waste from packaging, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have agreed to a plan to change their packaging and cut plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

She saw a child visiting from another country in Bangladesh playing with one.
Wasfia watched but did not play, because many people there thought girls should not use hula hoops or ride bikes.
Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world who have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro.
She is also the first person to hula-hoop on each mountain top.
She does this to help women and girls in her country feel strong and confident, even though many people there say girls should not do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: Based on our findings, we suggest that Girox Foods use a way of managing that cares about people. We should offer flexible hours and let employees choose where they work, for example at home. Managers should give staff new and interesting tasks. They should say “well done,” thank people for good work, and give rewards. We should also spend more money on training, especially training in how to talk and work with people from different cultures. These steps will help make a friendly, supportive place to work, so employees can do their best.

Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: Based on these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods use a more people-focused management style. As part of this, we should look for ways to offer more flexible working hours and to let employees work from locations they choose. Managers should find different ways to challenge our staff and give more praise, support, and recognition for their work. We should also invest more in staff training, especially in social communication and communication with people from other cultures. This will help create a positive workplace where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the past 200 years, better technology and health care meant fewer children died when they were young. Because of this, the number of people grew fast. Big families had many children. Many of these children lived to be adults and had their own children. But in the 1960s, birth control became easier to get. After that, the average number of babies each woman had in the world went down from about six to about two.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last two hundred years, better technology and health care meant fewer children died young. This led to fast population growth. Many families were large. Their children lived to become adults and had children of their own. In the 1960s, birth control became widely available. Since then, the average number of babies each woman has worldwide fell from about six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing there may be differences in what people expect and how they act can help us avoid misunderstandings. But we must also remember that cultural stereotypes can hurt good business relationships. A country’s culture can affect how we think and act. But many other things affect us too: our region, the groups we belong to, our age and gender, the culture in our company, and our own life experiences. So remember these differences, but do not use them to say that all people from one country are the same.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
Being more aware of different expectations and behaviour can help us avoid misunderstandings. But we must also remember that cultural stereotypes can harm good business relationships.

National culture can shape how we think and act. However, many other things also influence us: the region we come from, the communities we belong to, our age and gender, our company culture, and our own life experiences.

So keep these differences in mind, but do not use them to judge people or to treat everyone from one country as the same.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. It doesn't surprise me at all. This is a man who tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves and, when you listen to Born in the USA, those stories are as relevant today as they ever were.
candidate: Many famous singers slow down. But Springsteen is still making new music that many people love. He still plays big shows. He is still very good, even though he is almost 70 years old. I am not surprised. He tells important stories about our lives. When you listen to Born in the USA, these stories are still important today.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. candidate: Unlike many other famous singers, Springsteen is still releasing new music. His songs reach the top of the charts, and he still fills big stadiums. He is still at his best, even in his late sixties. I am not surprised. He tells important stories about our lives. When you listen to his album Born in the USA, those stories still matter today, just as much as before.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate:
There are more questions about how our genes help our brain and language grow.
Did some genes change and give humans the ability to speak?
Scientists found a change in a gene that happened 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.
This change may be connected to speaking and to how the brain moves the mouth and face.
Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not have this change.
We still do not know how important genes are for language.
Maybe, in the future, we will find the answers in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not have this change. It is too early to know how much genes affect language, but one day we might find the answers in our DNA.

source: Julie Wong is a leading researcher in the field of Robotics and AI. She has been published extensively as author and co-author of over 50 papers in highly regarded, peer-reviewed journals. She frequently speaks at international conferences and was awarded the prestigious Royal Academy Simone Fielding fellowship in 2012. Julie lives with her family in a smart home she designed herself.

She often speaks at big meetings around the world. In 2012, she won a top award from the Royal Academy called the Simone Fielding fellowship. Julie lives with her family in a smart home. She designed it herself.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.
candidate: NASA is now trying to find and record smaller asteroids. These are ones that are 140 metres wide or more. There may be about 25,000 asteroids of this size. So far, NASA has found about 8,000. About 17,000 are still not found. In 2013, a 19-metre asteroid exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia and hurt 1,200 people. So these medium-sized asteroids can be very dangerous if they come close to Earth.

source: Earthquakes damage all structures, including bridges. Luckily, this kind of collapse is relatively infrequent, especially with modern bridges. Engineers have learned to design bridges in earthquake zones on areas that are much more resistant to movement.
candidate: Earthquakes can damage many kinds of structures. They can also damage bridges. But bridges do not collapse very often, especially modern bridges. Engineers now design bridges for places with earthquakes. They choose ground that does not move much when the earth shakes. This makes the bridges safer.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. Every year one boy and one girl aged 12 to 18 are chosen from each district by lottery to compete in a battle in which only one person can survive. The chosen teenagers are called "tributes". The whole nation is forced to watch the event on television.

Each year, one boy and one girl aged 12 to 18 are picked from each district by drawing names from a box. They must fight in a game where only one person can stay alive. The chosen teenagers are called “tributes.” Everyone in the country has to watch it on TV.

source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. But in recent years, the world's press has been full of reports of wild animals coming into cities in bigger and bigger numbers. There have been bears in Vancouver parks, leopards on the streets of Mumbai and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when bigger animals come into our cities? Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?
candidate: In many cities and towns, you can easily see small animals like birds, squirrels, mice, and insects. But in the last few years, news around the world says there are more and more wild animals coming into cities. For example, there are bears in parks in Vancouver, leopards on the streets in Mumbai, and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when big animals come into our cities? Do people welcome them, or do people think they are dangerous or pests (= animals that cause problems)?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA has created a map of 1,400 PHAs, none of which are expected to be a threat in the next one hundred years. With technology already available, NASA can track these objects and make predictions about possible impact, at which point two defence solutions could be launched.
candidate: 'Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' (PHAs) are big space rocks. They can pass very close to Earth’s path around the Sun, as close as about 7.5 million kilometres. NASA has made a map of 1,400 PHAs. They are not a danger for the next 100 years. With tools we already have, NASA can watch these space rocks and say if one might hit Earth. If there is a risk, NASA could send up two types of defence to protect us.

If a real risk appears, two kinds of defence could be used.

source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. The only programmes she could find on TV were 'reality' programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars and news programmes about the war. Suzanne says that the two things start to merge together in a disturbing way and the idea for The Hunger Games came to her.

She could only find two kinds of shows: reality shows with real people trying to win a million dollars, and news about the war. Suzanne says these two things started to feel mixed together in a worrying way. Then she got the idea for The Hunger Games.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.
candidate:

It is the third book by the Canadian writer Yann Martel. It came out in 2001. Since then, it has sold more than seven million copies around the world. It has won many prizes and has been translated into 41 languages.

Martel is the son of a diplomat, a government worker who lives in other countries. When he was a child, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico.

source: Dreams of a phone call from an old friend or the death of someone close, for example, are more likely to be the result of coincidence than prophecy. And, of course, we probably choose to forget all the times we dream about such events but they don't happen.
candidate: For example, if you dream that an old friend will call you, or that someone close to you will die, it is usually just chance, not a sign of the future. Also, we often forget the many times we dream about these things and then nothing happens.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In some cases, this could happen because inferior-quality material was used in the construction, or because of a defect in a key piece of the bridge. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.
candidate: Sometimes a bridge falls down and no one knows why at first. Engineers find the reason only after a careful study. Sometimes it happens because weak materials were used to build the bridge. Sometimes an important part of the bridge has a problem. Other times, the bridge was made to hold only a certain weight, not more.

source: Some bridge collapses are mysteries, and engineers only realise why after they conduct a complete investigation. In other cases, the bridge was designed only to support a certain amount of weight and no more.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: I used to work five days a week. After I came back from leave to look after my children, I wanted to spend more time with them before they start school. I talked with my boss, and we agreed that I would work three days a week. This means I get less pay, because I am paid only for the days I work. But I still have the same amount of work. Now I do five days of work in three days, and I get paid much less.

I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

However, my amount of work has not gone down at all. I am now doing five days of work in three days, but getting paid much less.

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate:
Today, much business happens between people in different countries. Many people use English, but business talk and behavior can be very different in each culture.

If you do not know the local customs and ways of working, you may have unfair ideas about others. People may misunderstand each other, and there can be communication problems.

Here are three simple areas where business customs are different around the world. Knowing these can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.
candidate: Much of today’s business is international. Many people in global business use English as a shared language. If we do not understand the cultural rules and habits of the people we work with, we might judge them unfairly. We can also misunderstand them, and communication can have problems. Here are three basic areas where business manners differ around the world. Knowing these can help you when you work with someone from another culture.

source: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, though, we start to see the evidence of early human civilisation, through cave paintings for example; no one knows the connection between this and language. Brains didn't suddenly get bigger, yet humans did become more complex and more intelligent. Was it using language that caused their brains to develop? Or did their more complex brains start producing language?
candidate: Between 100,000 and 50,000 years ago, we start to see signs of how early humans lived. For example, they made cave paintings. We do not know how this is connected to language. Human brains did not suddenly get bigger. But people became smarter and could do more things. Did using language make their brains grow and change? Or did smarter brains create language?

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate: Many big supermarkets have been criticized in the last ten years. People say they threw away a lot of food, paid the people who sell goods to them too little, and used too much plastic to wrap products. This hurts the environment. But supermarkets and food shops are starting to listen. Because many customers are angry about plastic waste, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have joined an agreement to change how they wrap products and use less plastic.

In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate:

But supermarkets and food shops are starting to pay attention. Many customers are angry about the huge amount of plastic waste from packaging. In response, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have signed an agreement to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.
candidate: Wasfia Nazreen first saw a hula hoop when she was a young girl in Bangladesh. She saw a child from another country playing with it. She wanted to play too, but people in her country said girls should not use hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the very few people who have climbed the Seven Summits. She climbed Everest and Kilimanjaro too. She was the first person to hula hoop on the top of each mountain. She does this to help women and girls in Bangladesh feel strong and to show that they can do sports.

Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

Now she is one of the few people in the world to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent, like Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to hula hoop on each mountain top. She does this to give confidence to women and girls in a country where they are often told not to do sports.

Managers should find different ways to give staff new tasks that help them improve, and say “well done” and thank them for their work. We should spend more money on training, especially on how to talk and work with people from other cultures. These changes can help make a good place to work where employees can do their best.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate: Based on these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods use a more people-focused way of managing. As part of this, we should look for ways to offer flexible working hours. We should also consider how to let employees work from places they choose, such as home. Managers should find different ways to give staff new challenges and give more praise and recognize their good work. We should spend more on training, especially on communication with people from different cultures. This will help create a positive workplace where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate:
In the last 200 years, machines and medicine got better. So fewer children died, and more children lived. Because of this, the number of people in the world grew fast. Many families were big. Their children grew up and had their own children.

In the 1960s, birth control became easy to get. After that, women had fewer babies. On average, the number went down from about six babies per woman to about two.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, better technology and health care meant fewer children died. As a result, the population grew quickly. Big families had many children who lived to become adults and then had children of their own. But in the 1960s, birth control became widely available. After that, the global average number of babies per woman fell from about six to about two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
It helps to know that people from different places may expect different things and may act in different ways. This can help us avoid communication problems. But we must remember that simple ideas about a culture can be wrong. They can hurt good business relationships.

A country's culture can be important for how we think and act. But many other things matter too: the area we come from, the groups we belong to, our age, whether we are male or female, the culture at our company, and our own life experiences.

So, keep these differences in mind. But do not think that everyone from one country is the same. Treat each person as an individual.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Understanding that people may have different expectations and ways of acting can help us avoid misunderstandings. But it is very important to remember that cultural stereotypes can harm good business relationships. A person’s country can affect how they think and behave. However, many other things also shape us: the region we come from, the groups and communities we belong to, our age and gender, the culture at our workplace, and our own life experiences. So we should keep these possible differences in mind, but we should not use them to label or judge everyone from a country in the same way.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. It doesn't surprise me at all. This is a man who tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves and, when you listen to Born in the USA, those stories are as relevant today as they ever were.
candidate: Many famous artists stop making hit albums as they get older. Bruce Springsteen is different. He still makes new music that goes to number one, and he still fills big stadiums. He is still very good, even in his late 60s. This does not surprise me. He tells important stories about our lives. When you listen to Born in the USA, you can hear that these stories still matter today.
