source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

They want to change how they use packaging and use less plastic.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

Big families had lots of children who grew up and had their own children too. However, in the 1960s, it became easier for people to use birth control. Now, the average number of babies a woman has is lower – about two babies instead of six.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: It’s important to understand that people might have different ideas about what is right or normal. This can help us avoid misunderstandings. However, it’s also important to remember that judging people based on their country can be bad. We are all different – because of where we grew up, our friends, our age, our gender, our company, and what we have experienced. We should remember these differences, but not use them to make assumptions about everyone from a particular country.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

They found one gene that changed a long time ago – about 200,000 to 100,000 years ago. This gene seems to help us speak and control our mouths and faces. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it didn’t change. It’s not clear yet how much genes affect language, but maybe we will find the answers in our DNA in the future.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

NASA has found about 8,000 of them. This means they still need to find 17,000 more. In 2013, a much smaller asteroid exploded above a city in Russia called Chelyabinsk. This asteroid was only 19 metres wide. It hurt 1,200 people. So if these bigger asteroids come near Earth, they could be very dangerous.

source: The Hunger Games are an annual event, which the Capitol uses to remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling. source: Small animals like birds, squirrels, mice and insects are a common sight in many cities and towns. But in recent years, the world's press has been full of reports of wild animals coming into cities in bigger and bigger numbers. There have been bears in Vancouver parks, leopards on the streets of Mumbai and wild pigs in gardens in Berlin. What happens when bigger animals come into our cities? Are they welcome or are they considered a danger or a pest?
candidate:
Birds, squirrels, mice and insects are small animals. We often see them in cities and towns. But now, bigger wild animals are coming into cities too. This is happening more and more. Newspapers and TV news talk about this a lot. 

There are bears in parks in Vancouver. Vancouver is a city in Canada. There are leopards walking on streets in Mumbai. Mumbai is a big city in India. There are wild pigs in people's gardens in Berlin. Berlin is a city in Germany.

What happens when these big animals come to our cities? Do people like them? Or do people think they are dangerous? Do people think these animals cause problems?

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins was flipping between channels on TV. It was at the time of the US invasion of Iraq. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!
candidate: Before, I worked five days every week. Then I had a baby and stopped working for some time. When I went back to work, I wanted to spend more time with my children before they go to school. I talked to my boss about this. We decided I would work only three days each week. This means I get less money now because I work fewer days. But I found a problem: I still have the same amount of work to do! Now I do five days of work in only three days, but I get much less money for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

If you don't understand how people from other countries do business, you might have problems. You might not understand each other well, or you might think bad things about them. Here are three important differences in business manners around the world. These can help you when you work with people from different countries.

We have two questions: Did using language make their brains better? Or did better brains help them start making language? Nobody knows the answer.

source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.
candidate:
Big supermarkets have done some bad things in the last ten years. People are angry with them. The supermarkets have thrown away lots of food. They have not paid farmers enough money. They have used too much plastic for their food packages. All this plastic is bad for our world.

But now the supermarkets are listening to people. Many customers don't like all the plastic waste. They complain about it. So some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK have made a promise. They want to change their packages. They want to use less plastic. This will help our environment.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

These are very high mountains like Everest and Kilimanjaro. She was the first person to play with a hula hoop on top of each mountain. She did this to help women and girls in her country. In Bangladesh, many people think women and girls should not do sports.

Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to climb the Seven Summits. These include Everest and Kilimanjaro. She is also the first person to use a hula hoop on each mountain top. Her reason for doing this was to help women and girls feel stronger in a country that stops them from doing sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate:
We think Girox Foods should change how they work with their people. The company should be nicer to workers and think more about what workers need. Here are our ideas:

First, workers should have more choices about when they work. Some people work better in the morning, some work better at night. The company should let people choose their working hours.

Second, workers should be able to work from different places. Some people want to work from home. Some want to work in the office. The company should let people choose where they work.

Third, managers should give workers more interesting jobs to do. Workers like to learn new things and solve problems. When workers do good work, managers should say "well done" and "thank you."

Last, the company should help workers learn new skills. Workers should learn how to talk to different people and work with people from other countries. When workers learn new things, they are happier and do better work.

We should also spend more money on training staff, especially helping them learn better social and communication skills with people from different cultures. This could help create a good working environment where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology got better and people became healthier. This meant that fewer children died when they were young. Because more children lived, the number of people in the world grew very fast. These big families had many children. These children grew up and had their own children too. But in the 1960s, people could get contraception more easily. Contraception helps people choose when to have babies. Because of this, women around the world started having fewer babies. Before, women had about six babies each. Now, women have about two babies each.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
It is good to know that people from different countries may act differently or want different things. This can help us talk better with them and not have problems. But we must be careful. We should not think that all people from one country are the same. This is not true and it can make business relationships bad.

People act in certain ways because of their country's culture. But there are other things that change how people think and act. For example, where they live in their country, what groups they belong to, how old they are, if they are men or women, what their company is like, and what has happened to them in their life.

So we should remember that people might be different because of their culture. But we should not think that everyone from the same country acts the same way. Each person is different.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing that people from different cultures might have different expectations and ways of behaving can help us avoid misunderstandings. But it is very important to remember that cultural stereotypes can harm good business relationships. Although the culture of our country might influence how we behave and think, many other things also affect us. These include the area we come from, the groups we belong to, our age and gender, our company culture, and our personal experiences. So we should keep knowledge about cultural differences in the back of our minds, but we should not use it to put all people from one country into the same group.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

This happened between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. These changes may have helped humans learn to speak. The changed genes help our brains control our mouth and face when we talk. Monkeys have similar genes, but their genes did not change in the same way. Scientists are not sure yet how much genes help us with language. But maybe one day they will find the answer by looking at our DNA. DNA is like a book of instructions inside our bodies.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

They still need to find 17,000 more. In 2013, a small asteroid hit near a city called Chelyabinsk in Russia. This asteroid was only 19 metres wide. It hurt 1,200 people. So if the bigger asteroids come close to Earth, they will be very dangerous.

source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. After negotiating with my boss, we decided to cut my working week down to a three-day work week. This of course meant a significant cut in my pay too, as I'm paid on a pro-rata basis. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. source: Many of the major supermarket chains have come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts over the past decade. They've wasted tonnes of food, they've underpaid their suppliers and they've contributed to excessive plastic waste in their packaging, which has had its impact on our environment. But supermarkets and grocers are starting to sit up and take notice. In response to growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging, some of the largest UK supermarkets have signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage.

Because customers are increasingly angry about the large amounts of plastic waste created by plastic packaging, some of the biggest UK supermarkets have agreed to a plan that promises to change their packaging and reduce plastic waste.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

These are very high mountains like Everest and Kilimanjaro. She was the first person to play with a hula hoop on top of each mountain. She did this to help women and girls in her country, because many people there think women should not do sports.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. As part of this, we should explore ways of offering more flexible working hours to our employees and consider how we can enable employees to work from their chosen locations. Managers need to consider a variety of ways to challenge our staff and provide more positive reinforcement and recognition of the work they do. Increased investment in professional development, especially in the area of social and intercultural communication, could also contribute to creating a positive environment for employees to produce their best work.
candidate:
We studied Girox Foods and we have some ideas. We think the company should care more about its workers. Here are our ideas:

First, workers should have flexible working hours. This means they can choose when to start and finish work. Workers should also be able to work from home or other places they like.

Second, managers should give workers more interesting and difficult tasks. Managers should also say "good job" more often when workers do well.

Third, the company should spend more money on training. Workers need to learn how to talk to people better, especially people from different countries and cultures.

If Girox Foods does these things, workers will be happier and do better work.

Managers need to think of different ways to give our staff interesting work and give them more positive feedback and recognition for what they do. Spending more money on professional development, especially on social and intercultural communication skills, could also help create a positive environment where employees can do their best work.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: In the last 200 years, technology got better and people became healthier. This meant that fewer children died when they were young. Because more children lived, there were more people in the world. These big families had even more children. These children grew up and had their own children too. But in the 1960s, people could get contraception more easily. Contraception helps people choose when to have babies. Because of this, women around the world started having fewer babies. Before, women had about six babies each. Now, women have about two babies each.

But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

These large families had even more children who lived to become adults and then had their own children. But when contraception became easier to get in the 1960s, the average number of babies that women have around the world has dropped from six babies per woman to as low as two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate:
It is good to know that people from different countries may think and act differently. This can help us talk to them better and avoid problems. But we must be careful. We should not think that all people from one country are the same. This is wrong and can make business relationships bad.

People are different for many reasons. Yes, their country can change how they think and act. But there are other things too. Where they live in their country is important. The people they spend time with are important. Their age matters. If they are a man or woman matters. The company they work for can change them. All the things that happen in their life make them different.

So we should remember that people from different countries may be different. But we should not put all people from one country in the same group. Every person is different.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: Knowing about possible differences in what people expect and how they behave can help us avoid problems when we communicate. However, it is very important to remember that cultural stereotypes can damage good business relationships. Although national cultures might influence the way we behave and think, we are also strongly influenced by the region we come from, the communities we belong to, our age and gender, our company culture and our personal experiences. Therefore, knowledge of these possible differences should be something we keep in the back of our minds, rather than something we use to put all the people from one country into the same category.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. It doesn't surprise me at all. This is a man who tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves and, when you listen to Born in the USA, those stories are as relevant today as they ever were.

Springsteen sings about important things in people's lives. He has a famous album called 'Born in the USA'. When you listen to his songs, you can see that what he sings about is still important for people today.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate:
Scientists want to know if our genes help us learn language. Genes are very small things inside our bodies. They decide many things about us, like the color of our eyes.

Scientists think that long ago, between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, something changed in our genes. This change helped humans learn to speak. It also helped our brains control our mouths and faces when we talk.

Monkeys have genes that are like human genes. But monkeys don't have this special change in their genes. That's why monkeys can't speak like humans.

Scientists don't know everything about genes and language yet. But maybe one day they will find more answers. They will look at our DNA to learn more. DNA is like a book inside our bodies that tells us about our genes.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
candidate: There are more questions about how genetics affects brain and language development. Are there genes that changed and gave humans the ability to speak? Scientists have discovered a gene that changed between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This gene seems to be connected to speaking and how our brains control our mouths and faces. Monkeys have a similar gene, but theirs did not change in the same way. It is too early to know how much genes influence language, but one day we might find the answers in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. Of the 25,000 estimated asteroids of this size, so far about 8,000 have been logged, leaving 17,000 unaccounted for. Considering that a 19-metre asteroid that exploded above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013 injured 1,200 people, these middle-sized asteroids would be a serious danger if they enter Earth's orbit.

These middle-sized asteroids could be dangerous if they come near our planet.

source: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' are rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

Yann Martel’s father was a diplomat, and when he was a child, he lived in countries like Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. I've since noticed, though, that my workload hasn't decreased in the slightest! I'm now doing five days' worth of work in three days, but getting paid much less for it!

source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

If you don't understand the rules of how people behave in business in another country, you might make mistakes. You could also have misunderstandings and problems with talking. Here are three important things to remember when you work with someone from a different country: it’s about understanding their rules and customs.

source: Wasfia Nazreen first came across a hula hoop as a young girl, when she saw a foreign child who was visiting her native Bangladesh playing with one. Wasfia reluctantly stood by and watched, as in her country it was believed that girls should not play with hula hoops or ride bikes. Now Wasfia is one of the few people in the world to have climbed the Seven Summits, including Everest and Kilimanjaro, and the first to have hula-hooped on each peak. Her reason for doing so: to empower women and girls in a country which discourages them from doing sport.

source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: It’s important to understand that people might have different ideas about what is okay to do and how to behave. This can help us avoid misunderstandings. However, it’s also important to remember that ideas about cultures can be bad and make it hard to make good friends in business. Where we come from, like our country and our friends, our age, our gender, the company we work for, and our own experiences can all affect how we behave. So, we should think about these differences, but not make guesses about people just because they are from a different country.

So, it’s best to keep these differences in mind, but not to judge people based on their nationality.

source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

Monkeys have a similar gene, but it didn’t change in the same way. We don’t know yet exactly how much genes help us learn language. Maybe one day, we will find the answers in our DNA.

source: Now NASA is working towards logging some of the smaller asteroids, those measuring 140 metres wide or more. source: The Life of Pi tells the extraordinary story of Pi, a teenage boy from India, who is shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel is the son of a diplomat and as a child lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

Yann Martel’s father was a diplomat, and when he was a child, he lived in different countries, such as Costa Rica, Canada, France, and Mexico.

source: I used to do a typical five-day week, but after I came out of my parental leave, I decided that I wanted to spend more time with my children before they start school. source: Much of today's business is conducted across international borders, and while the majority of the global business community might share the use of English as a common language, the nuances and expectations of business communication might differ greatly from culture to culture. A lack of understanding of the cultural norms and practices of our business acquaintances can result in unfair judgements, misunderstandings and breakdowns in communication. Here are three basic areas of differences in the business etiquette around the world that could help stand you in good stead when you next find yourself working with someone from a different culture.

Here are three simple things that can help you when you work with people from different countries.

source: On the basis of these findings, we recommend that Girox Foods adopt a more people-oriented management style. source: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children. But with the wider availability of contraception in the 1960s, the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
candidate: For many years, people lived longer because of new machines and better medicine. This meant more children were born. These children grew up and had their own children. But in the 1960s, it became easier for women to stop having babies. Now, women usually have fewer babies – about two babies per woman, on average.

source: Having an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations and behaviour can help us avoid cases of miscommunication, but it is vital that we also remember that cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships. Although national cultures could play a part in shaping the way we behave and think, we are also largely influenced by the region we come from, the communities we associate with, our age and gender, our corporate culture and our individual experiences of the world. The knowledge of the potential differences should therefore be something we keep at the back of our minds, rather than something that we use to pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation.
candidate: It’s important to know that people might have different ideas about what is right or wrong. This can stop misunderstandings. But we also need to remember that it’s bad to think of people from other countries as all the same. The way we behave depends on many things: where we live, who we know, how old we are, if we are a man or a woman, and what we have learned in our jobs and in life. It’s good to remember these differences, but we shouldn’t use them to judge people from other countries.

So, it’s best to remember these differences, but not to assume that everyone from a particular country is the same.

source: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music and remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. source: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development. Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability? Researchers have found a gene mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago, which seems to have a connection with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not undergo this mutation. It's too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.

This gene might help us to speak and control our mouths and faces. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not change. We don't know yet how much genes affect language, but maybe we will find the answers in our DNA in the future.
